SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Includes." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Municipal Code will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

CHAPTER 1 - GENERAL GOVERNMENT 
1.01 Form of Government 1.02 Elected Officials 1.03 Appointed Officials 1.04 Boards and Commissions 1.05 Registration of Electors 1.06 Polling Place and Polling Hours 1.07 Aldermanic Districts 1.08 Crystal River Mill Pond Shoreline 1.09 Annexations 1.10 (Repealed) 1.11 Public Records 1.12 City Administrator  

1.01 - FORM OF GOVERNMENT. 
The City of Waupaca, Wisconsin operates under the Mayor-Council system of government under Ch. 62, Wis. Stats. 
1.02 - ELECTED OFFICIALS. 
The elected officials of the City shall consist of the following: 
(1)  MAYOR. Two-year term, elected in even-numbered years. 
(2)  ALDERPERSONS. Ten alderpersons, 2 from each aldermanic district, one elected each year for a 2-year term. 
1.03 - APPOINTED OFFICIALS. 
(1)  CITY CLERK. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #20-94; Rep. & Recr. Ch. Ord. #11-95) Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. 
(1a)  CITY TREASURER. (Cr. Ord. #20-94; Rep. & Recr. Ch. Ord. #11-95) Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. The Treasurer shall also perform the duties of the Comptroller. 
(2)  CITY ATTORNEY. Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. 
(3)  CITY ENGINEER-DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS. Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. He/she shall also perform the duties of the City Forester. 
(4)  ASSESSOR-BUILDING INSPECTOR-PLAN COORDINATOR. Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. 
(5)  (Rep. Ord. #17-96) 
(6)  CHIEF OF POLICE. See sec. 4.01(2) of this Code. 
(7)  FIRE CHIEF. See sec. 5.01(2) of this Code. 
(8)  STREET SUPERINTENDENT-WEED COMMISSIONER. Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. 
(9)  WATER SUPERINTENDENT. Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. 
(10)  SANITARY SUPERINTENDENT. Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. 
(11)  PARKS-RECREATION DIRECTOR. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #10-87) Appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for an indefinite term. 
(12)  (Rep. Ord. #4-86) 
1.04 - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS. 
Unless otherwise stated, appointments shall be made at the April organizational meeting of the Council and terms for such appointments shall commence on May 1 and end on April 30. 
(1)  BOARD OF REVIEW. (Am. Ord. #21-01) The Board of Review shall consist of the Mayor who shall act as chairperson, the City Clerk who shall serve as clerk, and 3 Alderpersons appointed by the Mayor. The members shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the Council for staggered 5-year terms. 
(2)  CITY PLAN COMMISSION. 
(a)  Membership . 
1.  The City Plan Commission shall consist of the Mayor who shall be its presiding officer, the City Engineer, the President of the Park and Recreation Board, an Alderperson and 3 citizens. Citizen members shall be persons of recognized experience and qualifications. 
2.  The Alderperson member of the Commission shall be elected by a 2/3 vote of the Council during each April. 
3.  The citizen members shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for 3-year terms with appointments staggered so that one member is appointed each year. 
4.  The City Assessor shall be an ex officio member of the Commission. 
(b)  Vacancies . Vacancies other than ex officio shall be filled by appointment for the residue of the unexpired term in the same manner as appointment for the full term. 
(c)  Compensation; Oath . No compensation shall be paid for service on the Commission. Citizen members shall take the official oath required by §19.01, Wis. Stats., which shall be filed with the City Clerk. 
(d)  Powers and Duties . The Commission shall have the powers and duties prescribed in §62.23, Wis. Stats., and all legislative enactments, amendatory thereof or supplementary thereto, and such other powers and duties as shall be vested in it, from time to time, by law or the Council. 
(e)  Organization . The Commission shall elect a vice chairperson and a secretary and shall keep a written record of its proceedings to include all actions taken, a copy of which shall be filed with the City Clerk. Four members shall constitute a quorum, but all actions shall require the affirmative approval of a majority of the members. 
(f)  Staff; Budget . The Commission may employ experts and such staff as may be necessary and may pay for their services and such other expenses as may be necessary and proper, within the limits of the budget established by the Council, or placed at its disposal through gift, and subject to any ordinance or resolution enacted by the Council. As far as possible, the Commission shall utilize the services of existing City officials and employees. 
(g)  Rules and Reports . The Commission may adopt rules governing its own proceedings. 
(3)  BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS. The Board of Zoning Appeals shall be appointed, pursuant to §62.23(7)(e), Wis. Stats. 
(4)  POLICE AND FIRE COMMISSION. 
(a)  Membership . The Police and Fire Commission shall consist of 4 citizens appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for terms of 5 years with appointments staggered so that no more than one citizen member is appointed each year. In addition, one Alderman shall be appointed by the Mayor annually. 
(b)  Powers and Duties . The Commission shall have the powers and duties designated by §62.13, Wis. Stats., including the "Optional Powers of Board," as set forth in §62.13(6), Wis. Stats., and such other powers and duties as the Council may, from time to time, designate. All provisions for administration of the Commission, appointments, additional powers and duties of the chiefs, organization of the departments, conduct of subordinates, leaves of absence, promotions, offenses and penalties for misconduct, charges, suspensions and trials shall be provided for in detail by the Commission, such "General Rules for Government of the Police and Fire Departments," upon its completion by the Commission, shall be adopted by the Council. 
(c)  Meetings, Reports, Budgets . All members of the Commission shall meet in a body with the Council at the regular Council meeting in June each year. The Commission shall present to the Council a full report of their activity for the past 12 months and shall discuss, in detail, all proposals of major importance having a direct effect on either Department which have not been approved by the Council. All reports of the Commission submitted to the Council shall be in writing and shall be signed by all 5 members. Should any member not be in accord with the majority, the Mayor shall see that the members be heard and the Council apprised of their views. The Commission shall submit a proposed budget at each October Finance Committee meeting for the coming year. 
(5)  (Rep. Ord. #15-87) 
(6)  LIBRARY BOARD. 
(a)  Membership . (Am. Ord.#07-03) The Library Board shall be appointed pursuant to §43.54, Wis. Stats., (as amended). In filling the appointment, at least one young person of high school age shall be appointed. In the event the youth must resign the position to attend college or any other reason, another youth shall be appointed to fill the unexpired term. 
(b)  Powers and Duties . The Library Board shall have such powers and duties as prescribed by law and such other powers and duties as shall be vested in it, from time to time, by the Council. Any proposed deviation from City personnel policies relating to library employees shall be referred to and approved by the Council. 
(7)  PARK AND RECREATION BOARD. (Am. Ord. #12-89; #3-96; #7-96; #07-03; #02-06). 
(a)  The Park and Recreation Board shall consist of 9 members. Two of the members shall be alderpersons, one of which shall also be a member of the Finance Committee. The Alderperson members shall be appointed by the Mayor annually. Three of the members shall be from the Towns of Dayton, Farmington and Waupaca. The town chairperson of each respective town shall appoint one board member to represent the town. The remaining 4 members shall be citizen members. The citizen members shall be citizens from the City, one of which shall be a senior citizen. The member elected President of the Board shall also be a resident of the City. The citizen members shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation of the Council, for 3-year terms with appointments staggered so that no more than 2 citizen members are appointed annually. 
(b)  The Board shall also have the care, supervision and control of the Lakeside Cemetery and shall be charged with landscaping and beautifying the same and caring for monuments, statues and trees, removing trees, planting new trees, herbage and appurtenances. The Board shall set standards for minimum requirements of foundations for monuments, the placing of monuments, statues, trees and shrubbery. The Board shall submit a budget each year to the Council for its approval. The Board shall establish the policy of the cemetery relating, but not limited to, the use, opening and closing hours, the establishment of tree nursery stock, loitering, speed limits on roads and maintenance of roads. The Board shall administer all gifts and bequests in accordance with the donees' wishes. The Board shall work with the Street Superintendent, sharing equipment of a priority basis established by the Street Superintendent and/or the Board of Public Works. The Board shall recommend to the Council all necessary land acquisition for the cemetery and costs, charges and assessments of graves and new roads. The Board shall have general supervision of the surveying of the grounds, provide for the proper platting, recording of plats or replats and maintaining an accurate record of the same. Section 157.07, Wis. Stats., shall not apply to the City. All plats, replats or maps of the cemetery shall be laid out and platted to the satisfaction of the Council. The Board shall cause the plat, replat or maps to be recorded in the office of the Register of Deeds. 
(8)  AIRPORT BOARD. 
(a)  Membership . (Am. Ord. #07-03) The Airport Board shall consist of 3 members, 2 citizens and one Alderperson, who shall be appointed by the Mayor for 6-year terms with appointments staggered so that one member is appointed every even-numbered year. In the event the Alderperson member ceases to be a member of the Council, he/she shall immediately cease to be a member of the Board and the Mayor shall appoint an Alderperson for the residue of the unexpired term. In addition, the Mayor shall appoint 3 citizens ex officio members for 2-year terms, provided that at least one of the ex-officio members is a youth. 
(b)  Powers and Duties . The Board shall have the powers and duties prescribed in §114.14, Wis. Stats., and such other powers and duties as shall be vested in it, from time to time, by law or the Council. 
(9)  ELECTION BOARD. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #2-86) The Election Board shall be selected pursuant to the provisions of §7.30(4), Wis. Stats., and shall consist of a minimum of 7 inspectors. In addition, the City Clerk may select tabulators, if needed, at compensation fixed by the Council, who shall assist and be under the direction of the election inspectors after the close of the poll. The City Clerk shall be responsible for training election workers. All officials, other than special registration deputies, shall be affiliated with one of the 2 recognized political parties which received the largest number of votes for president, or governor in nonpresidential general election years, in the ward or combination of wards served by the polling place at the last election. The party which received the largest number of votes is entitled to 4 inspectors for each polling place. The party receiving the next largest number of votes is entitled to 3 inspectors for each polling place. The same election officials may serve the electors of more than one ward where wards are combined. The compensation for each election official other than tabulators shall be set by the Council in the budget for the current year. Inspectors shall perform the duties of inspectors, clerks of election and ballot clerks, or wherever needed. The City Clerk may select alternates or may select 2 sets of inspectors to work at different times on election day, in accordance with §7.30(1), Wis. Stats., always maintaining the balance of the 2 parties, as described above. In accordance with §7.53(1), Wis. Stats., where the municipality constitutes one ward or combines all wards to utilize a single polling place under §5.15(6)(b), Wis. Stats., the canvass shall be conducted publicly under §7.51, Wis. Stats., and the inspectors shall act as the municipal board of canvassers. Upon completion of the canvass and ascertainment of the results by the inspectors, the City Clerk shall publicly read to the meeting the names of the persons voted for, the number of votes for each person for each office, the names of the persons declared by the inspectors to have won nomination or election to each office and the number of votes cast for and against each referendum. 
(10)  (Rep. Ord. #4-84) 
(11)  (Rep. Ord. #6-00) 
(12)  WATER COMMISSION. See sec. 13.01(2) of this Code. 
(13)  SEWERAGE COMMISSION. See sec. 13.02(3) of this Code. 
(14)  CABLE TELEVISION BOARD. (Cr. Ord. #15-84; Am. Ord. #13-89; #07-03; #15-03) 
(a)  Membership . The Cable Television Board shall consist of 5 members who shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, 4 of whom shall be citizen members and one who shall be an Alderperson. The Mayor shall appoint a Chairman of the Board. In the event the Alderperson member ceases to be a member of the Council, he/she shall immediately cease to be a member of the Board and the Mayor shall appoint an Alderperson for the remainder of the unexpired term. Any elector of the City may be appointed as a member of the Board. The Board shall meet during each year as often as necessary. 
(b)  Terms . Terms of the citizen board members shall be for 3 years and the term for the Alderperson member shall be for one year, commencing on May 1 of the year of appointment. The appointments shall be staggered the first year with 2 citizen members for 3 years, one citizen member for 2 years and one citizen member for one year. 
(c)  Powers and Duties . The Board shall have the following powers and duties: 
1.  The Board shall have the care, supervision and control of all television equipment belonging to the City and designated for use on cable television. 
2.  The Board shall oversee the Cable Television Ordinance (Chapter 19 of the City Code) and shall make recommendations to the City Council on matters affected by the Cable Television Ordinance and Cable Franchise agreement. 
3.  The Board shall select a WIN TV Coordinator with approval of the City Council and part time workers are as necessary. The Board shall oversee and direct the work of the WIN TV Coordinator and Staff, and any volunteer television production personnel. 
4.  The Board shall prepare and submit operating and capital budgets for review by the Finance Committee and for approval by the City Council. 
(d)  Priority Schedule . The Board shall establish a priority schedule, for the use of cable television facilities and manpower necessary for programming in the following order of priority. 
1.  The City of Waupaca. 
2.  Public schools. 
3.  Any other municipality served by cable television originating in the City may participate in programming board meetings and council meetings or other functions produced on their own equipment and compatible with the equipment owned by the City. Such use shall be on a time-available basis not in conflict with live productions scheduled by the City. Every effort should be made to schedule live events on a time basis not in conflict with the meetings of the Council. 
4.  Other City activities or community interest activities, all subject to the approval of the Cable Television Board. 
5.  In times of emergency, police and/or fire authorities shall preempt cable television for their use as long as required for public awareness. 
(e)  Programming/Equipment Usage Rules and Regulations . 
1.  Final approval of programming, scheduling, use of equipment, utilization of program participants and other matters deemed necessary rests with the Cable Television Board and final approval by the City Council. 
2.  Use of equipment shall only be allowed by properly trained participants. The WIN TV Coordinator shall make the determination on who may use the equipment. 
3.  Equipment utilization shall be accomplished through a checkout procedure established by the Board and Administered by the WIN TV Coordinator. All equipment must be signed out by properly trained and designated participants. 
4.  Proper care and maintenance of equipment is to be utilized at all times by all participants. Care and maintenance must be performed in accordance with the procedures described in the equipment manual. Equipment manuals shall be maintained by the WIN TV Coordinator. 
5.  Priority of time utilization for equipment shall be determined by the Board. 
6.  Utilization of equipment for personal purpose and any other use outside of approved programming for cable television shall not be allowed. 
7.  Utilization of equipment to raise money for the City's cable access shall only be allowed with the recommendation of the Board and with the approval of the City Council. 
8.  All contacts with outside agencies, individuals and organizations regarding cable television operations must be directed to the Chairman of the Cable Television Board and must be recommended by the Board and approved by the City Council. 
9.  All complaints regarding utilization of program participants, programming or other matters shall be directed to the Chairman and the Board. 
10.  All purchase of goods, services and capital equipment by the Cable Television Board shall be done in accordance with sec. 3.05 Waupaca City Code. 
11.  All other matters regarding the operation of cable television not covered by the above shall be subject to interpretation and determination by the Board with approval by the City Council. 
(15)  WELLHEAD PROTECTION COMMISSION. (Cr. Ord. #13-92; Am. Ord. #6-93) 
(a)  Membership . (Am. Ord. #07-03) The Wellhead Protection Commission shall consist of 11 members appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for terms of 5 years. The members shall be the Town Chairpersons or their designees from the Towns of Dayton, Lind, Waupaca and Farmington; one member from the Waupaca County Water Quality Committee; one Alderperson; the U.W. Extension Office Resource Agent for Waupaca County; and 4 citizen members, of which one must be a youth who may reside either in the City or surrounding towns. 
(b)  Powers and Duties . The Commission shall have the duty of developing a wellhead protection area, identification and location of potential contaminant sources within the wellhead protection area; assessment of the adequacy of existing programs to protect ground water from identified contaminant sources; and development of plans and recommendations for establishing zoning restrictions, ordinances and other programs to minimize the chances of future contamination. The Commission shall also be authorized to make recommendations concerning future well sites, purchases of land for future well sites and restrictions on certain land uses. The Commission shall be authorized to develop a comprehensive strategy and plan to protect the areas which supply ground water to the City's public water supply wells. 
(c)  Organization . (Am. Ord. #01-04) The Commission shall elect a chairperson, a vice chairperson and a secretary and shall keep a written record of its proceedings to include all actions taken, a copy of which shall be filed with the City Clerk. 
(d)  Rules and Reports . The Commission may adopt rules governing its own proceedings. 
(e)  Advisory Capacity; Expenditures . The Commission shall function in an advisory capacity and report its findings and recommendations to the Board of Public Works. All expenditures of the Commission shall, upon approval of the Board of Public Works, be charged to the Water Utility Fund. 
(16)  UNEXCUSED ABSENCES. (Cr. Ord. #4-86; Renum. Ord. #14-92) More than 3 unexcused absences in one year shall be cause for removal of a citizen member of a board or commission and the Mayor and the Council shall, after due notice and hearing on the matter and after consideration of the recommendation of the Chairperson of such board or commission, determine if such absences of a member of the board or commission is excused or inexcusable and act thereon. 
1.05 - REGISTRATION OF ELECTORS. 
No elector of the City may vote at any election or referendum held in the City unless he/she has been previously registered as an elector therein with the City Clerk, except as provided in §6.55, Wis. Stats. 
1.06 - POLLING PLACE AND POLLING HOURS. (Am. Ord. #8-91; #9-96; #16-00) 
(1)  POLLING PLACE. (Am. Ord. #01-08) The polling place for all 5 aldermanic districts shall be at The Recreation Center, 407 School Street, Waupaca, Wisconsin. 
(2)  POLLING HOURS. 
(a)  The polls at any election shall be open from 8:00 A.M. to 8:00 P.M. 
(b)  Any elector waiting to vote, whether within the polling booth or in the line outside the booth at the time the polls officially close, shall be permitted to vote. 
1.07 - ALDERMANIC DISTRICTS. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #9-81; #8-91; Am. Ord. #21-98; Rep. Recr. Ord. #4-00; #5-00; #20-01; #05-11) 
The City shall be divided into 5 Aldermanic Districts and 11 Wards, the numbers and boundaries of which shall be as follows: 
(1)  WARD 1. All of that portion of the City of Waupaca bounded by the following described line: Commencing at the intersection of N. Western Ave. and the northernmost lane of W. Fulton St. (westbound lane) said intersection located south of the NW corner of Section 30 (T22N R12E); thence northeast along said northernmost lane of W. Fulton St. to its intersection with Hillcrest Dr.; thence north and northeast along Hillcrest Dr. to its intersection with N. Morton St.; thence north along N. Morton St. to its intersection with North St.; thence east along North St. to its intersection with Scott St.; thence north along Scott St. to its intersection with Wisconsin St.; thence west along Wisconsin St. to its intersection with N. Harrison St. (aka State Highway 49); thence north along N. Harrison St. (aka State Highway 49) to its intersection with the City of Waupaca corporate limits; thence west along said corporate limits to its intersection with Brainerd Dr.; thence north along said corporate limits (also Brainerd Dr.) to the location where said corporate limits turn west away from Brainerd Dr.; thence west along said corporate limits; thence north along said corporate limits; thence west along said corporate limits; thence south along said corporate limits; thence east along said corporate limits; thence north along said corporate limits; thence east along said corporate limits; thence south along said corporate limits to its intersection with N. Western Ave.; thence south along N. Western Ave. to the point of beginning. This ward will be part of Aldermanic District 1, Supervisory District 10 and consists of 655 people. 
(2)  WARD 2. All of that portion of the City of Waupaca bounded by the following described line: Commencing at the intersection of E. Lake St. and S. State St. said intersection located in the SW of the NW Section 29 (T22N R12E); thence north along S. State St. to its intersection with E. Badger St.; thence west along E. Badger St. to its intersection with S. Division St.; thence north along S. Division St. to its intersection with E. Badger St.; thence continue north along an extension of S. (a)  One in the office of the Public Service Commission. 
(b)  One in the office of the City Clerk. 
(c)  One in the office of the Register of Deeds for Waupaca County, Wisconsin.

1.10 - RESERVED. (Rep. Ord. #1-91) 
1.11 - PUBLIC RECORDS. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #05-04) 
(1)  DEFINITIONS. 
(a)  Authority . Any City entity having custody of a City record, i.e., an office, elected official, agency, board, commission, committee, council, department or public body corporate and politic created by constitution, law ordinance, rule or order, or a formally constituted subunit of the foregoing. 
(b)  Legal Custodian . That officer, department head, division head or employee of the City designated under sub. (3) below or otherwise responsible by law to keep and preserve any City record or file, deposit or keep such records in his or her office, or is lawfully in possession or entitled to possession of such public records and who is required by this section to respond to requests for access to such records. 
(c)  Record . Any material on which written, drawn, printed, spoken, visual or electromagnetic information is recorded or preserved, regardless of physical form or characteristics, which has been created or is being kept by an authority. "Record" includes, but is not limited to, handwritten, typed or printed pages, maps, charts, photographs, films, recordings, tapes (including computer tapes), computer printouts and optical disks. "Record" does not include drafts, notes, preliminary computations and like materials prepared for the originator's personal use or prepared by the originator in the name of a person for whom the originator is working; materials which are purely the personal property of the custodian and have no relation to his or her office; materials to which access is limited by copyright, patent or bequest; and published materials in the possession of an authority other than a public library which are available for sale, or which are available for inspection at a public library. 
(d)  Record Subject . An individual about whom personally identifiable information is contained in a record. 
(e)  Requester . A person who requests inspection of or copies of a record. 
(2)  DUTY TO MAINTAIN RECORDS. 
(a)  Except as provided under sub. (8) below, each officer and employee of the City shall safely keep and preserve all records received from his or her predecessor or other persons and required by law to be filed, deposited or kept in his or her office or which are in the lawful possession or control of the officer or employee or his or her deputies, or to the possession or control of which he or she maybe lawfully entitled as such officer or employee. 
(b)  Upon the expiration of an officer's term of office or an employee's term of employment, or whenever the office or position of employment becomes vacant, each such officer or employee shall deliver to his or her successor all records then in his or her custody and the successor shall receipt therefore to the officer or employee, who shall file said receipt with the City Clerk. If a vacancy occurs before a successor is selected or qualifies, such records shall be delivered to and receipted for by the City Clerk, on behalf of the successor, to be delivered to such successor upon the latter's receipt. 
(3)  LEGAL CUSTODIANS. 
(a)  Each elected official is the legal custodian of his or her records and the records of his or her office, but the official may designate an employee of his or her staff to act as the legal custodian. 
(b)  Unless otherwise prohibited by law, the City Clerk or the City Clerk's designee shall act as legal custodian for the Council and for any committees, commissions, boards or other authorities created by ordinance or resolution of the Council, or, in his or her absence or disability, or in case of vacancy, the deputy clerk is hereby designated the legal custodian of all City records. 
(c)  For every authority not specified in pars. (a) or (b) above, the authority's chief administrative officer is the legal custodian for the authority, but the officer may designate an employee of his or her staff to act as the legal custodian. 
(d)  Each legal custodian shall name a person to act as legal custodian in his or her absence or the absence of his or her designee. 
(e)  The legal custodian shall have full legal power to render decisions and to carry out the duties of an authority under Ch. 19, Subch. II, Wis. Stats., and this section. The designation of a legal custodian does not affect the powers and duties of an authority under this section. 
(4)  PUBLIC ACCESS TO RECORDS; FEES. 
(a)  Except as provided in sub. (6) below, any requester has a right to inspect a record and to make or receive a copy of any record, as provided in §19.35(1), Wis. Stats. 
(b)  Records shall be available for inspection and copying during all regular office hours. 
(c)  A requester shall be permitted to use facilities comparable to those available to City employees to inspect, copy or abstract a record. 
(d)  The legal custodian may require supervision during inspection or may impose other reasonable restrictions on the manner of access to an original record if the record is irreplaceable or easily damaged. 
(e)  A requester shall be charged a fee to defray the cost of locating and copying records, as follows: 
1.  Unless a fee is otherwise specifically established or authorized to be established by law, the cost of photocopying shall be $0.25 per page. The cost has been calculated not to exceed the actual, necessary and direct cost of the production. 
2.  If the form of a written record does not permit copying, the actual and necessary cost of photographing and photographic processing shall be charged. 
3.  The actual full cost of providing a copy of other records not in printed form on paper, such as films, computer printouts and audio or videotapes, or optical disks, shall be charged. 
4.  If mailing or shipping is necessary, the actual cost thereof shall also be charged. 
5.  There shall be no charge for locating a record unless the actual cost therefore exceeds $50, in which case the actual cost shall be determined by the legal custodian and billed to the requester. 
6.  The legal custodian shall estimate the cost of all applicable fees and may require a cash deposit adequate to assure payment if such estimate exceeds $5. 
7.  Elected and appointed officials of the City shall not be required to pay for public records they may reasonably require for the proper performance of their official duties. 
8.  The legal custodian may provide copies of a record without charge or at a reduced charge where he/she determines that waiver or reduction of the fee is in the public interest. 
(f)  Pursuant to §19.34, Wis. Stats., and the guidelines therein listed, each authority shall adopt and prominently display and make available for inspection and copying at its offices, for the guidance of the public, a notice containing a description of its organization and the established times and places at which, the legal custodian from whom, and the methods whereby the public may obtain information and access to records in its custody, make requests for records, or obtain copies of records, and the costs thereof. This paragraph does not apply to members of the Council. 
(5)  ACCESS PROCEDURES. 
(a)  A request to inspect or copy a record shall be made to the legal custodian. A request shall be deemed sufficient if it reasonably describes the requested record or the information requested. However, a request for a record without a reasonable limitation as to subject matter or length of time represented by the record does not constitute a sufficient request. A request may be made orally, but a request must be in writing before an action to enforce the request is commenced under §19.37, Wis. Stats. Except as provided below, no request may be refused because the person making the request is unwilling to be identified or to state the purpose of the request. No request may be refused because the request is received by mail unless prepayment of a fee is required under sub. (4)(e)6., above. A requester may be required to show acceptable identification whenever the requested record is kept at a private residence or whenever security reasons or Federal law or regulations so require. 
(b)  Each custodian, upon request for any record, shall, as soon as practicable and without delay, either fill the request or notify the requester of the authority's determination to deny the request, in whole or in part, and the reasons therefore. If the legal custodian, after conferring with the City Attorney, determines that a written request is so general as to be unduly time consuming, the party making the request may first be required to itemize his/her request in a manner which would permit reasonable compliance. 
(c)  A request for a record may be denied as provided in sub. (6) below. If a request is made orally, the request may be denied orally unless a demand for a written statement of the reasons denying the request is made by the requester within 5 business days of the oral denial. If a written request is denied in whole or in part, the requester shall receive a written statement of the reasons for denying the request. Every written denial of a request shall inform the requester that if the request for the record was made in writing, then the determination is subject to review upon petition for a writ of mandamus under §19.37(1), Wis. Stats., or upon application to the Attorney General or a district attorney. 
(6)  LIMITATIONS ON RIGHT TO ACCESS. A legal custodian shall have the right to withhold and to limit access or inspection of records in accordance with §§19.35(1) and 19.36, Wis. Stats., which are made a part hereof by reference. 
(7)  NOTICE TO RECORD SUBJECT; RIGHT TO ACTION. 
(a)  No legal custodian is required to notify a record subject prior to providing a requester access to a record containing information pertaining that record subject except as authorized and required by §19.356, Wis. Stats., which is made apart hereof by reference. 
(b)  No person is entitled to judicial review of the decision of an authority to provide a requester with access to a record except as authorized and required by §19.356, Wis. Stats., which is made a part hereof by reference. 
(8)  DESTRUCTION OF OBSOLETE RECORDS. 
(a)  Financial Records . City officers are empowered to destroy the following nonutility records under their jurisdiction after the completion of an audit by the Department of State Audit or an auditor licensed under Ch. 442, Wis. Stats., but not less than 7 years, unless a shorter period has been fixed by the public records board under §16.61(3)(e), Wis. Stats., after payment or receipt of the sum involved in the applicable transaction: 
1.  Bank statements, deposit books, slips and stubs. 
2.  Bonds and coupons after maturity. 
3.  Cancelled checks, duplicates and check stubs. 
4.  License and permit applications, stubs and duplicates. 
5.  Payrolls and other time and employment records of personnel included under Wisconsin Retirement Fund. 
6.  Receipt forms. 
7.  Special assessment records. 
8.  Vouchers, requisitions, purchase orders and all other supporting documents pertaining thereto. 
(b)  Utility Records . City officers are empowered to destroy the following records of municipal utilities subject to regulation by the State Public Service Commission and after an audit as provided above, but not less than 2 years unless a shorter period has been fixed by the public records board under §16.61(3)(e), Wis. Stats., after payment or receipt of the sum involved in the applicable transaction: 
1.  Water and sewer stubs and receipts of current billings. 
2.  Customers' ledgers. 
3.  Vouchers and supporting documents pertaining to charges not included in plant accounts. 
4.  Other utility records after 7 years with the written approval of the State Public Service Commission. 
(c)  Police Department Records . The Police Chief, or his/her designee, is empowered to destroy Police Department records, but not less than 7 years unless a shorter period has been fixed by the public records board under §16.61(3)(e), Wis. Stats., after the records, were effective or created. Police Department records include all records, as defined by sub. (1)(c) above, and include, by way of enumeration, but not limitation, the following: 
1.  Any case record of a traffic, misdemeanor, ordinance or civil case, including proceedings under Chs. 51 and 55, Wis. Stats. 
2.  Administrative records, including telephone log books, daily activity reports, daily complaint records, Ambulance/Fire Department dispatch records, statistical summaries, employee work schedules, court calendars, dockets and uniform traffic accident reports. 
(d)  Other Records . City officers are empowered to destroy the following records, but not less than 7 years, unless a shorter period has been fixed by the public records board under §16.61(3)(e), Wis. Stats., after the records were effective. 
1.  Assessment rolls and related records, including Board of Review minutes. 
2.  Contracts and papers relating thereto. 
3.  Correspondence and communications. 
4.  Financial reports other than annual financial reports. 
5.  Insurance policies. 
6.  Justice dockets. 
7.  Oaths of office. 
8.  Reports of boards, commissions, committees and officials duplicated in the official Council minutes. 
9.  Resolutions and petitions. 
10.  Voter record cards. 
(e)  Notice Required . Prior to the destruction of any public record described above, at least 60 days' notice shall be given the State Historical Society unless said notice has been waived by said Society. 
(f)  Limitation . This section shall not be construed to prevent the destruction of any public record after any other period allowed by statute or State administrative regulations or a period established by the Public Record Board. 
(9)  PRESERVATION THROUGH OPTICAL DISK OR ELECTRONIC FORMAT. Any City Officer or the director of any department or division of City government may, subject to the approval of the Council, keep and preserve public records in his/her possession by means of optical disk or electronic format or other photographic reproduction method. Such records shall meet the standards set forth in §§16.61(7)(a) and (b), and 16.612, Wis. Stats., and shall be considered original records for all purposes. Such records shall be preserved along with other files of the department or division and shall be open to public inspection and copying according to the provisions of State law and of subs. (4) through (7) above. 
1.12 - CITY ADMINISTRATOR. (Cr. Ch. Ord. #16-03) 
(1)  OFFICE OF THE CITY ADMINISTRATOR. In order to provide the City of Waupaca with a more efficient, effective and responsible government under a system of a part-time Mayor and part-time Common Council (hereinafter referred to as "Council") at a time when city government is becoming increasingly complex, there is hereby created the Office of City Administrator for the City of Waupaca (hereinafter referred to as "Administrator"). 
(2)  APPOINTMENT, TERM OF OFFICE AND REMOVAL. The Administrator shall be appointed on the basis of merit with due regard to training, experience, administrative ability and general fitness for the office, by a 2/3 vote of the Council and Mayor. For the purposes of appointing or terminating the Administrator, the Mayor and each Alderman shall cast one vote. The Administrator shall hold office for an indefinite term subject to removal at any time by a 3/4 vote of the Council and Mayor, at pleasure. This section, however, shall not preclude the Council from establishing other employment terms and conditions not inconsistent with the provisions of this section or the Municipal Code of the City of Waupaca. 
(3)  FUNCTIONS AND DUTIES OF THE ADMINISTRATOR. The Administrator, subject to the limitations defined in resolutions and ordinances of the City of Waupaca and Wisconsin State Statutes, shall be the chief administrative officer of the City, responsible only to the Mayor and the Council for the proper administration of the business affairs of the City, pursuant to the statutes of the State of Wisconsin, the ordinances of the City of Waupaca, and the resolutions and directives of the Council with duties, responsibilities and subject to conditions as maybe set forth by employment contract between the City and said City Administrator.
