5.01 - FIRE DEPARTMENT . 
(1)  COMPOSITION. The Fire Department of the City shall consist of the Fire Chief, 4 Assistant Chiefs (first, second, third and fourth Assistant Chiefs), Fire Inspector, Secretary-Treasurer and not less than 15 active firemen to make a minimum complement of 22 active firemen. 
(2)  APPOINTMENT, TERMS, DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS. The Police and Fire Commission shall appoint the Fire Chief, who shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by the Commission for cause. The Chief shall appoint subordinate members of the Department, subject to approval by the Police and Fire Commission. Such appointments, promotions, suspensions and removals shall be made as provided in §62.13, Wis. Stats., which section is hereby adopted by reference. 
(3)  REGULATIONS. Members of the Department shall be governed by the rules and regulations adopted by the Police and Fire Commission and resolutions and ordinances of the Council and the Wisconsin statutes. 
5.02 - FIRE CHIEF, POWERS AND DUTIES . 
The Fire Chief shall direct the operation of the Department at fires, subject to the rules and regulations which may be adopted by the Council and the Police and Fire Commission, issue and enforce such orders as in his/her judgment may be best calculated for the protection of property and the extinguishing of fires; enforce all ordinances and rules and regulations of the Council governing the Fire Department; report annually to the Council all fires occurring in the City, the origin thereof, if possible, together with the amounts and value of property destroyed and the amount of insurance, if any; make a full statement of the condition of the Department at the end of each year and make further reports when ordered to do so by a resolution of the Council or required to do so by the rules and regulations of the Police and Fire Commission. He/she shall report promptly to the Commission any member of the Department who may have disobeyed his/her orders or violated any of the rules governing the Department and shall have control and supervision of the fire alarm. 
5.03 - ASSISTANT CHIEFS, DUTIES . 
In the absence of the Chief, the highest ranking Assistant Chief shall take command and perform his/her duties. 
5.04 - FIRE INSPECTOR . 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. The Fire Inspector shall be appointed by the Fire Chief and approved by the Police and Fire Commission. 
(2)  POWERS AND DUTIES. The Fire Inspector shall personally, or through his/her duly authorized deputy, make such inspections as may be necessary to ascertain the compliance of the owners or occupants of private premises with the provisions of this chapter, and he/she and his/her assistants may enter any building or upon any premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of such inspection. Should he/she find a fire hazard, he/she may serve a notice, in writing, on the owner of the property, giving the owner 48 hours in which to remove the hazard. If the fire hazard is not removed within that time, it is deemed a nuisance and the Fire Inspector may have the same removed by the City and the cost of removal shall be recovered by the City as a special charge, pursuant to §66.0627, Wis. Stats. 
(a)  FREQUENCY OF INSPECTIONS. (Cr. Ord. #07-16(2016)) The inspections shall be conducted at least once per calendar year, the interval between those inspections shall not exceed 15 months. 
(3)  INVESTIGATION AND RECORD OF FIRES. The Fire Inspector shall investigate the cause of all fires occurring within the City as soon as possible after their occurrence and he/she shall keep a record thereof, and of the evidence in each case, on file in his/her office as a public record. 
5.05 - FALSE ALARMS . 
Whoever, without reasonable cause, by outcry or otherwise, makes any false alarm of fire shall be penalized under sec. 5.25 of this chapter. 
5.06 - USE OF ADJACENT PROPERTY . 
Any fireman, while acting under the order or direction of the Chief or other officer in command, may enter upon the premises adjacent to or in the vicinity of any building or other property then on fire for the purpose of extinguishing such fire and no person shall hinder or resist or obstruct any fireman in the discharge of such duty. 
5.07 - DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY TO CHECK PROGRESS OF FIRE . 
During the progress of any fire, the Fire Chief, or in his/her absence the Assistant Chief or squad leader in charge, may order the removal or destruction of any property necessary to prevent the further spread of fire. 
5.08 - APPARATUS TO AND FROM FIRES . 
Except when actually responding to a fire alarm or other emergency call, or when on duty at a fire, the apparatus of the Fire Department shall have no special right of way or privileges of any kind, but shall be subject to the same traffic regulations as other vehicles. 
5.09 - TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY TO VOLUNTEERS . 
All volunteer firemen, when responding to a fire call with a private vehicle, shall comply with all traffic regulations. 
5.10 - SAFETY REGULATIONS . 
The Chief or his/her designated agent may prescribe certain limits in the vicinity of any fire within which any persons, excepting firemen and policemen and those admitted by order of any officer of the Fire Department, shall not be permitted. He/she may cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire, or to prevent the spreading of fire, or to protect adjoining property. He/she may likewise cause the shut-off of electrical and natural gas services where the same create a dangerous hazard or interfere with the work of the Fire Department during the progress of the fire. 
5.11 - DUTY OF BYSTANDERS . 
Every person who may be present at a fire shall be subject to orders of the Chief or other officer in command and every such person shall render assistance as may be ordered by the officer in charge. Any person who shall refuse to obey such order after the official status of the officer in charge shall be made known to him/her shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec. 5.25 of this chapter. 
5.12 - DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT AND INTERFERENCE . 
No person shall willfully hinder a fireman in the discharge of his/her duties, nor shall any person willfully injure in any manner any hose, fire engine or other fire apparatus belonging to the City. 
5.13 - DRIVING OVER FIRE HOSE . 
No road vehicle shall be driven over any fire hose unless otherwise directed by an officer of the City. 
5.14 - COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS . 
No person shall permit on premises he/she controls any empty boxes, waste paper, excelsior, rags or other combustible materials in such quantities or manner as to create a fire hazard. 
5.15 - CARELESS SMOKING PROHIBITED . 
(1)  No person shall, by careless or willful smoking or use of lighters or matches in smoking, whether intentional or unintentional, set fire to personal property or any building. 
(2)  A plainly printed notice of this section shall be posted in a conspicuous place in every sleeping room of every place renting rooms for the accommodation of the public. Such printed notices shall also be posted in any place of public assembly where smoking is permitted. 
(3)  The Fire Chief shall post, or cause to be posted, "No Smoking" signs on any premises or in any building or any section of such premises or building where by the presence of highly combustible materials, in his/her opinion, the act of smoking presents a fire hazard. Such signs shall be not less than 10 inches by 12 inches in size and shall be posted conspicuously at intervals of not less than 30 feet. Such signs shall bear the words "No Smoking" across the top in large letters, state the authority by which they are posted in smaller letters and bear the signature of the Fire Chief or his/her duly authorized representative. 
(4)  Candles or torches that are not in a fixed holder shall not be allowed to be burned. Lighted candles held in the hands shall not be allowed in any church or public building unless written permission is first obtained from the Fire Chief or Assistant Fire Chief. 
5.16 - GASOLINE, BENZINE, NAPHTHA, ETC . 
All gasoline stations, bulk gasoline storage facilities, and any facility for storing benzine, naphtha or any other volitile liquid shall be constructed and maintained in conformity with the regulations prescribed by the State statutes and the rules and regulations of the State Department of Industry, Labor and Human Relations 
5.17 - GUNPOWDER . 
No person shall keep or store more than 5 pounds of gunpowder at any place within the City without the written permission of the Fire Chief. Any dealer, permitted to keep at his/her place of business in excess of 5 pounds of gunpowder, shall not keep more than 50 pounds at any one time, and such gunpowder shall be kept in a safely constructed box painted yellow with the word "powder" printed or painted thereon in black letters not less than 5 inches in height and equipped with handles so that the same may be readily moved in case of fire, and such box shall be kept in such part of the dealer's place of business as may be directed by the Fire Chief. 
5.18 - DYNAMITE . 
No person shall keep or store within the City any nitroglycerine, dynamite, giant powder or other explosives more violent than gunpowder without the written permission of the Fire Chief or otherwise than in accordance with the conditions prescribed in such permission as granted and in no case shall more than 25 pounds of any such explosive be stored or kept within 20 roads of any dwelling or other occupied building. The Fire Chief may direct the place and the manner of keeping the same and the precautions to be observed in connection therewith. 
5.25 - PENALTY . 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or any order, rule or regulation made hereunder, and any fireman who shall neglect or refuse to perform any duty required hereunder, shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec. 25.04 of this Code. 
CHAPTER 6 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #02-13) 
6.01 Name 6.02 Objective 6.03 Policy and Purpose 6.04 Membership 6.05 Committees 6.06 Miscellaneous Provisions 6.07 Emergency Response Plan 6.08 Rules 6.09 Amendments  

6.01 - NAME. 
The name of this organization shall be the City of Waupaca Local Emergency Planning Committee of, hereinafter referred to as the "LEPC". 
6.02 - OBJECTIVE. 
The role of the City of Waupaca LEPC is to form a partnership with local government agencies and industries as a resource for enhancing emergency response and preparedness. Local governments are responsible for the integration of hazmat and all hazards planning and response within the jurisdiction. This includes ensuring the local hazard analysis adequately addresses hazmat incidents; incorporating planning for hazmat incidents into the local emergency management plan and annexes; assessing capabilities and developing hazmat response capability using local resources, mutual aid and contractors; training responders; and exercising the plan. 
6.03 - POLICY AND PURPOSE. 
To ensure that the City of Waupaca is capable of responding in the event of an emergency with the underlying goal of minimizing the effects from a disaster and ensure a timely recovery. To accomplish this through emergency response training, updating emergency response resource listings, public awareness campaigns and improving communications between public agencies and the general public. 
The purpose of the LEPC shall be to carry out those responsibilities required pursuant to Section 301(c) of Public Law 99-499, the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act (EPCRA) of 1986, also known as SARA Title III, and related regulations. The plan shall be reviewed and updated as necessary on an annual basis in accordance with Section 303 of SARA, Title III. 
The LEPC shall, in addition: 
(1)  Receive and process request for information from the public under the Right-To-Know provisions; 
(2)  With the information and reports from facilities operating within the jurisdiction of the LEPC, and an analysis of the district's transportation risks, the LEPC will perform a hazard analysis; 
(3)  Establish and maintain a database of hazardous chemical locations and quantities in the district; 
(4)  Establish and maintain a computerized system of data management; 
(5)  Maintain detailed information on all facilities which manufactures, or stores, extremely hazardous substances (EHS) and include the information within the emergency response and preparedness plan; 
(6)  Develop training and testing of a emergency response plan. 
The LEPC will make assessments of resources necessary to implement the emergency response and preparedness plan, and make recommendations to appropriate people, agencies, and organizations regarding additional resources needed to implement the plan. 
The LEPC shall be instrumental in fulfilling the purpose of the Community Right-To-Know laws to increase the protection of the community from exposure to chemicals produced, used, stored and/or transported within the City. Transportation hazards analysis will include those risks to the district from commercial transportation by rail, highway, aircraft, and waters of commerce. 
6.04 - MEMBERSHIP. 
Membership will at all times include, at a minimum, representatives of the groups listed in Section 301 of SARA, Title III. At a minimum the committee shall have equal representation from: 
 Local elected officials 
 City of Waupaca Office of Emergency Management 
 City of Waupaca Dept. of Public Works 
 City Assessor 
 City administrative departments 
 Waupaca Police Dept. 
 Waupaca Area Fire District 
 Waupaca Area Ambulance 
 Waupaca County 911 
 Riverside Medical Center 
 Disaster relief agencies (Red Cross or Salvation Army) 
 Broadcast and print media personnel 
 Community groups 
 Owners or operators of local facilities. 
The members will be appointed by the Mayor of the City of Waupaca, and approved by the City of Waupaca Common Council. 
The responsibilities of the Committee shall include the review and update of the City of Waupaca Emergency Operations Plan as necessary, exercising or training on the plan, implementing public awareness programs, ensuring compliance with Ch. 323, Wis. Stats., governing emergency government, assisting with Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and state of Wisconsin disaster reporting and any other activity that will complement or enhance emergency planning and response in the City. 
The membership of the LEPC shall consist of officers and a staff. The officers may consist of a Chairperson, a Vice-Chairperson, Emergency Management Coordinator, an Information Coordinator, and a Secretary. 
(1)  TERMS OF MEMBERSHIP. Members shall be residents of or have a business affiliation in City of Waupaca. 
(2)  TERMS OF OFFICE. Membership of the LEPC may select the terms of office to be either one or 2 years. Existing officers may be re-elected to their existing offices if they so indicate a willingness to continue. 
(3)  THE CHAIRPERSON. The appointed alderman shall serve as the Chairman of the LEPC. The Chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the LEPC unless he/she cannot be present at an announced meeting. The Chairperson shall serve as an ex-officio member of all committees, and shall perform such duties and acts as necessary to accomplish the goals of the LEPC. The Chairperson shall be empowered to create such other Ad Hoc Committees as necessary to accomplish the goals of the LEPC. 
(4)  THE VICE-CHAIRPERSON. Upon resignation, or death, or the advice of the Chairperson, the Vice-Chairperson shall perform the duties of the Chairperson. The Vice Chairperson shall perform such other duties as may be assigned by the Chairperson. 
(5)  THE SECRETARY. The Secretary in cooperation with the Information Coordinator shall be the custodian of all books, papers, documents, and other property of the LEPC. 
(6)  EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT COORDINATOR. The Emergency Management Coordinator position shall be appointed by the Mayor with confirmation by Common Council. The position shall serve a term of one-year. The Emergency Management Coordinator shall serve on the City of Waupaca LEPC and fulfill the roles, activities and responsibilities of the position identified in Ch. 323, Wis. Stats. 
(7)  THE INFORMATION COORDINATOR. The LEPC will appoint an Information Coordinator. This person will process request from the public for information under Section 324, including Tier Two information under Section 312. The coordinator will assist the Secretary in records management. The Information Coordinator will be a non-voting member of all committees of the LEPC. 
(8)  INACTIVE MEMBERS. Appointed members shall be considered inactive when he/she have missed more than 2 unexcused Committee meetings without notification to the Committee Chair of significant reason why they were unable to attend the meetings. An annual report listing members declared inactive will be provided to the Executive Advisory Panel and the LEPC. 
(9)  REMOVAL OF MEMBERS. The City of Waupaca LEPC may ask that the Mayor remove a member from its roll. 
(10)  VACANCIES. Any vacancy occurring in the LEPC by reason of resignation, death, or disqualification of a member will be filled by the nomination of the LEPC Chairperson and appointed by the Mayor. 
(11)  ALTERNATES. Every approved member of the LEPC Committee may select an alternate to attend meetings in his/her absence. The alternate may participate in discussions, and will have voting rights. If both the regular member and his/her alternate are in attendance at a regular scheduled LEPC meeting, the regular member's privileges and responsibilities will supersede those of his/her respective alternate. 
6.05 - COMMITTEES. 
(1)  EXECUTIVE ADVISORY PANEL. The Executive Advisory Panel will consist of the LEPC Chairperson, Vice-Chairperson, Secretary, and Emergency Management Coordinator. The duties of the Executive Advisory Panel will assist in coordinating the activities of the Subcommittee and Ad Hoc Committees. 
(2)  SUBCOMMITTEES. The following Subcommittees may be established: 
(a)  Right-To-Know Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for the formulation of all policies and procedures concerning the public's Right-To-Know program; the formulation of all chemical release reporting procedures, the establishment of trade secret protection procedures, and the formulation of all record keeping and information dissemination procedures for the LEPC. 
(b)  Emergency Management Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for reporting the status of NIMS training, State and National Emergency Management initiatives, Emergency Management Logistics, and the coordination between the City of Waupaca and Waupaca County Emergency Management. 
(c)  Training and Exercise Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for the coordination of multi agency collective training and exercises. 
(d)  Law Enforcement/Communications Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for reporting the coordinating efforts of law, order and security agencies, and coordination and implementation of interoperable communications between first responding agencies within City of Waupaca. 
(e)  Fire Services Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for reporting the status of resources, assets, training, personnel and mutual aid agreements as it pertains to fire support functions, search and rescue, and hazmat response within the City of Waupaca. 
(f)  Emergency Medical Services and Hospitals Subcommittee . This Committee will report on the coordination and planning efforts between EMS First Responders and hospital. 
(g)  Public Works Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for reporting the status of and coordinating the emergency management efforts between the City of Waupaca Department of Public Works, and corresponding agencies within all municipalities. 
(h)  Transportation and Evacuation Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for reporting the status of transportation resources, and evacuation planning. 
(i)  Mass Care and Shelter Task Force Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for reporting the coordination efforts with the American Red Cross and all Faith Based Organizations as it pertains to mass care and sheltering operations. 
(j)  Social Services Committee . This Committee will be responsible for reporting the status of social and mental health services under emergency conditions. 
(k)  Public Alerting, Information and Education Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for reviewing the public alerting and notification systems; public relations with affected communities and the public at large, and development of public awareness, education and information programs. 
(l)  Volunteers and Donations Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for coordinating with regional volunteers and faith based organizations. 
(m)  Animal Control Subcommittee . This Committee will be responsible for the sheltering, evacuation and rescue of domesticated animals. 
(3)  AD HOC COMMITTEES. The Chairperson may create the Ad Hoc Committee as necessary to perform the functions of the LEPC. Chairpersons of Ad Hoc Committees shall be appointed by the Chairperson of the LEPC. 
(4)  CHAIRPERSONS OF THE SUBCOMMITTEES. The Chairperson of the Subcommittee shall be nominated and elected by their respective committees. The election shall be by ballot, except that when there is only one nomination for each office, election may be by voice vote. 
(5)  MEMBERSHIPS IN SUBCOMMITTEES. All members must volunteer to serve on at least one Subcommittee and shall not serve on more than 3 Subcommittees. Final membership of the Subcommittee shall be determined by the Chairperson after consultation with the Executive Advisory Panel to ensure that all Committees have sufficient manpower to carry out their assigned tasks. 
(6)  MEETINGS. Meetings of the Subcommittee and Ad Hoc Committees may be called by the Chairperson of the LEPC or the Chair of the Committee as deemed necessary. 
(a)  Regular Meetings . The LEPC Committee and Subcommittees shall meet at a minimum bi-monthly. 
(b)  Special Meetings . The LEPC Chairperson may call such special meetings as may be deemed necessary to carry out duties of the LEPC. Upon the written request of at least 50 percent of the members the LEPC Chairperson shall call a meeting within 10 days. 
(7)  QUORUM. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the LEPC members, excluding those members declared to be inactive. A quorum shall be required to transact business. 
(8)  ANNUAL REPORT. Annually in May of each year the Committee shall prepare a written report to the Common Council detailing the activities undertaken for the previous year. 
(9)  AGENDA. Any member may request that the LEPC Chairperson place an item on the meeting agenda. If the Chairperson should decline to do so, a member may have such item placed on the agenda by submitting it in writing to the Chairperson with support signatures of 50 percent of the members. 
(10)  RULES OF ORDER. The deliberations of all meetings of the LEPC and its subcommittees shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order. 
(11)  NOTICE OF MEETINGS. Notice of time, date, place of meeting, and agenda items to be considered at each meeting shall be given in writing to all members at least 6 days prior to each meeting by the staff or the LEPC Chairperson. 
A notice of the regular meeting schedule of the LEPC shall be published and posted at City Hall and available to the media with regular circulation in City of Waupaca in accordance with SARA, Title III (EPCRA). This notice shall specify the meeting designated specifically for receipt of public comments on the emergency plan. 
6.06 - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. 
(1)  FISCAL YEAR. The fiscal year shall be considered to run from January 1 to December 31. 
(2)  INDEBTEDNESS. All indebtedness incurred by the LEPC shall be approved by the LEPC Chairperson before payment. 
(3)  APPROVAL OF BYLAWS. These bylaws shall become effective upon approval of majority vote by those in attendance at an organized meeting. 
(4)  DISQUALIFICATION. Any member who is unable to attend a meeting of the LEPC may notify the Chairman or Secretary. Any member with 5 or more absences is subject to disqualification at the request of the LEPC Chairperson. This disqualification request will be forwarded to the Mayor for final approval. 
6.07 - EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN. 
The LEPC Committee is responsible for the development and update of the City of Waupaca Emergency Response Plan. The plan is designed to complement and reference back to the Waupaca County Emergency Response Plan. There shall be training or "exercising" of the plan on a periodic basis to allow emergency response agencies within the City an opportunity to train. 
6.08 - RULES. 
EPCRA requires that the LEPC shall establish rules by which the committee shall function. Such rules shall include provisions for public notification of committee activities, public meetings to discuss the emergency plan, public comments, response to such comments by the committee, and distribution of the emergency plan. 
(1)  METHOD OF INITIATING PROPOSED RULE-MAKING. Any member of the LEPC may recommend the initiation of proposed rule-making. Any proposed rules shall be initially considered by the Executive Advisory Panel, unless otherwise decided by the LEPC. If the Executive Advisory Panel, by majority vote approves the proposed rule, it shall thereafter proceed to publication as provided in the preceding section. 
(2)  METHOD OF ADOPTING FINAL RULES. Following the expiration of the 10-day comment period, the Executive Advisory Panel shall review all public comments and prepare a statement which responds to comments raised and discusses the basis for any appropriate changes to the proposal. The Executive Advisory Panel shall present such statement to the LEPC. The LEPC shall then vote on the adoption of the proposed rule. If the vote is favorable, the rule shall take effect immediately upon the time and date the notice of adoption is first published. 
(3)  EMERGENCY RULES. In emergency circumstances, the LEPC may adopt rules without prior public notice and comment, provided that no such rule will remain in effect for more than 90 days. 
(4)  In accordance with Section 324 of the SARA Title III Act, all information obtained from an owner or operator pursuant with EPCRA and any requested Tier Two forms or Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) otherwise in possession of the LEPC shall be made available to any person submitting a written request under this section. If the owner should request the location of a specified chemical not be identified, the LEPC shall withhold that information. 
(5)  All photocopied information requests by a member of the public shall be provided at the sole expense of the requestor(s). The cost of such reproduction shall be set by the Information Coordinator, with the approval of the Executive Advisory Panel, at a level that will enable the LEPC to recover all reasonable expenses associated with the processing of the request. 
(6)  REQUEST FOR MSDS'S AND OTHER NON-CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION. Any person may obtain an MSDS with respect to a specific facility by submitting a written request to the LEPC Information Coordinator. The facility shall provide the MSDS copy with [within] 45 days of the written request. Any person may request any other non-confidential information concerning a facility, which may be held by the LEPC by submitting a written request to the LEPC Information Coordinator. 
(7)  REQUESTS FOR TIER TWO INFORMATION. Any person may request Tier Two information with respect to a specific facility by submitting a written request to the LEPC in accordance with the following requirements: 
(a)  If the Committee does not have in its possession the Tier Two information as requested, it shall request a submission of the particular Tier Two form from the owner or operator of the facility subject to the request, provided that the request is from a state or local official acting in his or her official capacity or the request is limited to hazardous chemicals stored at the facility in an amount in excess of the threshold planning quantity. 
(b)  If the request does not meet the requirements of the LEPC may request submission of the Tier Two form from the owner or operator of the facility subject to the request if the request includes a general statement of need. 
(8)  The City of Waupaca LEPC shall take an all hazard approach when conducting risk assessments and emergency planning within the City. 
6.09 - AMENDMENTS. 
These by-laws may be amended as necessary. These bylaws may be amended by the Waupaca Common Council. Any member of the LEPC shall have the right to comment on or suggest revisions to the bylaws. 
CHAPTER 7 - TRAFFIC CODE

7.01 - STATE TRAFFIC LAWS ADOPTED . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #13-02; Am. Ord. #11-03) 
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, the statutory provisions in §§110.075, 938.343 and Chs. 340 to 348, Wis. Stats., describing and defining regulations with respect to vehicles and traffic, exclusive of any provisions therein relating to penalties to be imposed and exclusive of any regulations for which the statutory penalty is a fine or term of imprisonment are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated herein are intended to be made part of this chapter in order to secure uniform state-wide regulation of traffic on the highways, streets and alleys of the State of Wisconsin. 
7.02 - OFFICIAL TRAFFIC MAP AND CONTROL DEVICES; PROHIBITED SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKERS . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #18-02) 
(1)  DUTY OF THE DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS TO ERECT AND INSTALL UNIFORM TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES. Whenever traffic regulations created by this chapter, including a State traffic regulation adopted by reference in sec. 7.01 of this chapter, require the erection of traffic control devices for enforcement, the Director of Public Works shall procure, erect and maintain uniform traffic control devices conforming to the Uniform Traffic Control Device Manual promulgated by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation, giving notice of such traffic regulations to the users of the streets and highways on which such regulations apply. Whenever State law grants discretion to local authorities in erecting or placing of a uniform traffic control devices, devices shall be erected in such locations and in such a manner as, in the judgment of the Director of Public Works, will carry out the purposes of this chapter and give adequate warning to users of the streets and highways of the City. 
(2)  OFFICIAL TRAFFIC MAP. 
(a)  Official Traffic Map Established . The There is hereby established for the City of Waupaca an Official Traffic Map dated August 12, 2002, by MSA Professional Services of Baraboo, Wisconsin, upon which is indicated as of said date all existing traffic signage including no parking areas, restricted parking areas, stop signs, arterial intersections, yield signs, special speed limits, one way highways, school crossings signs and all other restrictions or limitations contained in this chapter and which the laws of the State require the erection or use of official traffic control devices to enforce such restrictions or limitations. All such signage restrictions and limitations set forth on said Official Traffic Map are hereby adopted, ratified and affirmed. 
(b)  Additions, Deletions or Changes to Map . The Common Council, may from time to time, make additions, deletions or changes to the Official Traffic Map. Every addition, deletion or change to the Official Traffic Map shall indicate the number of the authorizing ordinance or resolution and the date the traffic control device was erected, altered or eliminated. 
(c)  Official Traffic Map to Be Maintained . A copy of the Official Traffic Map shall be maintained and displayed in the Office of the City Assessor/Building Inspector, the Police Department and Public Works Department. The City Assessor/Building Inspector's Office shall be charged with the upkeep and maintenance of the Official Traffic Map and in so doing shall make appropriate, authorized changes by hand within 3 working days after the official traffic control device is erected or removed, as the case may be. Periodically, but no less than every 3 years the Official Traffic Map shall be updated to include all additions, deletions or changes that have been made to the map by hand over the previous time period. 
(d)  Violations Prohibited . When official traffic control devices giving notice of restrictions, prohibitions and limitations shown on the Official Traffic Map are erected and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section, a violation of the restriction, prohibition or limitation shown on the Official Traffic Map shall be a violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  PROHIBITED SIGNS AND MARKERS IN HIGHWAYS. No person, other than a city official authorized by this chapter to erect and maintain official traffic control devices or his/her designee, shall place within the limits of any street or highway maintained by the City any sign, signal, marker, mark or monument unless permission is first obtained for the Director of Public Works or the State Highway Commission. Any sign, signal, marker, mark or monument placed or maintained in violation of this subsection shall be subject to removal, as provided in sub. (4) below. 
(4)  REMOVAL OF UNOFFICIAL SIGNS, MARKERS, SIGNALS AND TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES. The Director of Public Works or his/her designee, may remove any sign, signal, marker or device which is placed, maintained or displayed in violation of this chapter or State law. Any charge imposed against a premises for removal of a prohibited or illegal sign, signal, marker or device shall be reported by the Director of Public Works to the Common Council for review and certification at its next regular meeting following the imposition of the charge. Any charge not paid on or before the next succeeding November 15 shall be placed upon the tax roll for collection as other special municipal taxes. 
7.03 - SPEED LIMITS . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #06-10) 
The Council hereby determines that the statutory speed limits on the following city streets (excluding township, county or state roadways or highways) or portions thereof are unreasonable, unsafe, and imprudent and modifies such speed limits as follows: 
(1)  SPEED LIMITS CHANGES. Speed limits are increased or decreased as follows upon the following designated city streets (excluding township, county or state roadways or highways) or portions thereof: 
(a)  35 Miles Per Hour : 
Apple Tree Lane: Farm Drive to Runway Drive/Commercial Drive 
Commercial Drive: Apple Tree Lane to east end 
Runway Drive: Apple Tree Lane to east end 
Churchill Street: Apple Tree Lane to Evans Street 
Ware Street: Mainline Railroad right-of-way east of Miller Street to Tower Road (CTH K) 
Royalton Street: Matheson Street to Tower Road (CTH K) 
(b)  Speed Limit on Alleys : The speed on any alley located within the City shall not exceed 5 miles per hour. 
7.04 - THROUGH HIGHWAYS . 
(1)  THROUGH HIGHWAYS DESIGNATED. In the interest of public safety and pursuant to authority granted by Wisconsin law, the Council, by resolution, has previously declared certain highways, or portions thereof, to be through highways. 
(2)  DESIGNATION OF LOCATION OF STOP SIGNS AND YIELD SIGNS. In the interest of public safety, the Council, by resolution, has designated the location of stop and yield signs within the City and has ordered the installation of such signs. 
(3)  OPERATORS TO OBEY TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES. Every operator of a vehicle approaching an intersection at which an official traffic control device is erected in accordance with this section shall obey the direction of such official traffic control device as required by the Wisconsin Statutes incorporated by reference in sec. 7.01 of this chapter. Operators of vehicles approaching a stop sign shall stop before entering a highway, as required by §345.46, Wis. Stats. Operators approaching intersections at which a yield sign has been installed shall yield the right of way to other vehicles, as required by §346.18(5), Wis. Stats. 
7.045 - ONE WAY STREETS . (Rep. & Recr. #03-14) 
The following streets are designated one-way streets and no person shall operate a vehicle thereon in any direction, except as follows: 
(1)  Granite Street - northwesterly only, from Hillcrest Drive to Morton Street. 
(2)  Shearer Street - southeasterly only, from Van Street to School Street. 
(3)  Van Street - northerly from School Street to Shearer Street. 
7.05 - PARKING REGULATIONS . 
(1)  PARKING PROHIBITED DURING CERTAIN PERIODS. No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle or personal property for longer than 30 minutes between 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M. upon any parking lot in which the City has an interest, except the parking lot located at the southwest corner of the intersection of South Washington Street and West Union Street and the parking lot know as Riverside Parking Lot located between North Main Street and the Waupaca River. 
(2)  STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING OF VEHICLES. The authority vested in the Council under §349.13, Wis. Stats., to prohibit, limit the time of, or otherwise restrict the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles beyond the prohibitions, limitations or restrictions imposed by Ch. 346, Wis. Stats., is delegated to the Chief of Police. 
(3)  NO PARKING EXCEPT FOR AUTHORIZED VEHICLES. Except as herein permitted, no person shall park, stop or leave standing any vehicle in the following places unless authorized by an official traffic control sign: 
(a)  At any curb area marked as a taxi stop or stand. 
(b)  At any curb or municipal parking lot area designated as parking for City personnel. 
(4)  PARKING ZONE REGULATIONS. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #3-82) 
(a)  Definitions . Whenever in this subsection the following terms are used, they shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
1.  Street. Every way set apart for public travel, except alley ways, bridle paths and foot paths. 
2.  Roadway. That portion of a street between curb lines and the adjacent property lines. 
3.  Vehicle. Any device by which any person or property may be transported upon a public highway, except those operated upon rails and permanent tracks. 
4.  Parking Zone. A certain designated and marked-off section of the public street within the marked boundaries where the vehicle may be temporarily parked and allowed to remain for such period of time as the parking zone area signs hereinafter referred to may indicate. 
(b)  Parking Zones . Parking zones, as defined in par. (a)4. above, are hereby created on the following streets of the City: 
1.  Main Street, between Granite Street and the south line of the U.S. Post Office premises extended east, on both sides. 
2.  Granite Street, between Main Street and Washington Street, on both sides. 
3.  Sessions Street, between Main Street and Washington Street, on both sides. 
4.  Fulton Street, between Jefferson Street and Washington Street, on both sides. 
5.  Union Street, between Division Street and Washington Street, on both sides. 
6.  Badger Street, between Main Street and Washington Street, on both sides. 
7.  Jefferson Street, between Fulton Street and Badger Street, on both sides. 
8.  Washington Street, between West Fulton Street and Badger Street, on both sides. 
9.  From time to time hereafter, as traffic conditions require on such streets and avenues, or such other locations as selected by resolution of the Council for the location of such zones. 
(c)  Limitations on Parking . In said parking zones, no person shall cause a vehicle to be parked for a period of time in excess of the following times on the following named streets or portions thereof: 
1.  15 Minute Parking. (Am. Ord. #10-04; #02-08) 
a.  On South Main Street, from Badger Street to the south line of the U.S. Post Office premises extended east. 
b.  On the west side of South Washington Street from Union Street to the north line of the Police Department premises extended east. 
2.  8 Hour Parking. (Am. Ord. #10-04; Am. Ord. #12-18) On the east and west side of Jefferson Street, from East Union Street to East Fulton Street, including parking in the adjacent City Hall/Library parking lot within this block, unless signed otherwise. 
3.  2 Hour Parking. (Am. Ord. #10-04) All other parking zones. 
a.  To restrict parking along the North side of Badger Street between Franklin Street and Washington Street all to 2-hour parking limit. (Cr. Ord. #11-13) 
4.  Parking Prohibited in Certain Specified Places . (Cr. Ord. #1-87) No person shall stop or leave standing in any of the following places, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading or receiving or discharging passengers and while the vehicle is attended by a licensed operator so that it may promptly be moved in case of an emergency or to avoid obstruction of traffic. 
a.  In a loading zone, but in no case shall a vehicle be stopped or left standing in a passenger loading zone in excess of 3 minutes nor in a freight loading zone in excess of 30 minutes. The parking restrictions of this subparagraph shall be applicable only during the hours specified on official signs. 
b.  In an alley in a business district. 
c.  In any street or alley which is less than 18 feet wide from curb to curb. 
d.  Within 10 feet of a fire hydrant unless a greater distance is indicated by an official traffic sign. 
e.  Within 4 feet of the entrance to an alley or private road or driveway or bicycle way. 
f.  Closer than 20 feet to the near limits of a marked crosswalk. 
g.  Upon any portion of a highway where and at the time when parking is prohibited, limited or restricted by official traffic signs. 
h.  Upon any portion of a street right of way between the curb line or the edge of the roadway and the property line, said space being commonly known as the terrace, except for bicycle parking. (Am. Ord. #24-04) 
i.  On a street adjacent to the entrance of a school, church, theater, hotel, hospital or any other place of public assemblage during the hours designated by an official sign. 
j.  Not closer than 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a street. 
k.  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a street or within a street tunnel except parking shall be allowed on the bridge located on Water Street. (Am. Ord. #05-03) 
l.  On both sides of Evans Street at all times. (Cr. Ord. #13-96) 
m.  On the south side of Riverside Drive, between Churchill Street and Ninth Street. (Cr. Ord. #15-96) 
n.  On the south side of Mill Street, from State Street west to the alley, at all times. (Cr. Ord. #22-96) 
o.  On the west side of South Main Street, between Deer Street and Lake Street. The parking zone restrictions on the east side of South Main Street between Deer Street and Lake Street are vacated. (Cr. Ord. #10-99) 
p.  On Western Avenue, from West Fulton Street to Smith Street. (Cr. Ord. #17-00; Am. Ord. #24-02) 
q.  On the west side of Franklin Street, from the corner of Franklin Street and Union Street proceeding north for a distance of 65 feet, as indicated by official traffic signs. (Cr. Ord. #25-00) 
r.  On the east side of Franklin Street, between Union Street and Fulton Street. (Cr. Ord. #25-00) 
s.  On the south side of Ware Street, from the west right of way line of Oak Street to 60 feet east of the east right of way line of Oak Street. (Cr. Ord. #14-01) 
t.  From 200 feet north of the north side of the Elm Street right-of-way to the Wisconsin Central Ltd. Railroad right-of-way. (Cr. Ord. #17-01) 
u.  On the north side of Shoemaker Road, between the driveways to the Waupaca Middle School. On the south side of Shoemaker Road, from Riverside Drive east 100 feet. (Cr. Ord. #23-01) 
v.  On the east side of Morton Street from North Street to the north side of Hillcrest Drive and on the west side of Morton Street from the south side of Hillcrest Drive to the north side of Union Street. (Cr. Ord. #12-03-2003) 
w.  On Churchill Street from the intersection of Evans Street to the City Limits. (Cr. Ord. #24-04) 
x.  On both sides of Ridgeway Lane. (Cr. Ord. #24-04) 
y.  On the east side of Western Avenue from the intersection of W. Fulton Street, south 900 feet. (Cr. Ord. #14-05, Rltd. MCC '06) 
z.  To restrict parking on both sides of Brainerd Drive and Bailey Street from the Waupaca River north to a point 1,600 feet south of Larsen Road. (Cr. Ord. #10-08) 
aa.  To restrict parking on the north side of W. Union Street from Franklin Street to High Street. (Cr. Ord. #05-10) 
bb.  To restrict parking along the West side of State Street from Mill Street to Badger/School Streets. (Cr. Ord. #09-13) 
cc.  On both sides of Hillcrest Drive. (Cr. Ord. #08-15(2015)) 
dd.  To restrict parking on the north side and south side of Riverside Drive from Churchill Street to Shoemaker Road and the south side of Shoemaker Road from Riverside Drive 358 feet east. (Cr. Ord. #10-15(2015)) 
ee.  On the east side 9 th Street from Riverside Drive to Park Avenue. (Cr. Ord. #06-16(2016)) 
5.  The Chief of Police may exempt volunteer firefighters from the provisions of subpars. 1. through 3. above. The Chief may issue to volunteer firefighters a special exemption permit which shall be displayed in the vehicle so that the permit is visible to a police officer or other enforcement officer. The purpose of this exemption is to facilitate firefighters in responding to a fire or other emergency call. (Cr. Ord. #11-98) 
(d)  Designation of Parking Spaces . (Am. Ord. #15-87) For said parking zones, the Judiciary, Traffic, Safety and Parking Committee shall, as in its judgment may be necessary for the regulation, control and inspection of the parking of vehicles therein, reserve loading zones for commercial vehicles and shall cause such spaces to be designated as hereinafter provided. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subsection to park any motor vehicle exceeding 22 feet in length in any parking zone. 
(e)  Marking and Signing Parking Spaces; Enforcement . (Am. Ord. #15-87) The Judiciary, Traffic, Safety and Parking Committee, with the aid of the Board of Public Works, shall have markings painted or signs placed upon the curb and/or upon the street adjacent to parking zone areas above designated for the purpose of designating markings so established. No person shall park any vehicle across any such line or marking, or park said vehicle in such position that the same shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines or markings. The Committee shall provide the Police Department with adequate chalk marking devices so that they may mark the tires of vehicles parked so as to determine the period of time such vehicle is parked in a parking zone. 
(f)  Parking Times. (Am. Ord. #10-04) The parking limit in all parking zones shall be designated by appropriate signs posted in proximity to said parking zone areas. The limited parking in the zone shall apply only from 9:00 A.M. to 5:00 P.M. on Monday through Friday. The limited parking shall not be enforced on Saturday, Sunday, New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. 
(g)  Citations . (Am. Ord. #15-87) All police officers acting in accordance with instructions issued by the Judiciary, Traffic, Safety and Parking Committee shall report the following: 
1.  The type of vehicle occupying the parking space and has been parking in violation of any of the provisions of this subsection. 
2.  The state license number and make of such vehicle. 
3.  The time such vehicle is parking in violation of any of the provisions of this subsection. 
4.  Any other facts or knowledge which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(h)  Reserved . (Rep. Ord. #8-00) 
(i)  Collection of Penalties . (Am. Ord. #15-87) The Judiciary, Traffic, Safety and Parking Committee shall designate such collectors and methods as are necessary to properly collect all penalties deposited in the penalty boxes or mailed to or deposited with the City police. Such collectors shall be only such employees as are now or hereafter designated and duly bonded in a sum not less than $1,000 for the faithful performance of their duties. The City Clerk shall maintain a separate account at all times of such money so deposited. All forfeiture fees collected by the Police Department shall be deposited with the Clerk and credited to the forfeitures and fines account. 
(j)  Removal of Chalk Marks Prohibited . (Am. Ord. #10-87) No person shall alter or cause the removal of a regulatory chalk mark as provided in this subsection, and the penalty for such violation shall be $25. 
(k)  Farm Produce Sales . (Am. Ord. #10-87; #15-87) The Judiciary, Traffic, Safety and Parking Committee shall designate parking zones that may be used by farm market trucks for the sale of their own agricultural products, and an application may be obtained from the City Clerk for a yearly permit for a permit fee of $75, and such permit holder is then not limited to the time limitations provided in this subsection. 
(l)  Rental Spaces . (Am. Ord. #10-87; #15-87) The Judiciary, Traffic, Safety and Parking Committee, under the direction of the Council, shall designate parking zones rental spaces and the Council, by resolution, shall adopt a schedule of rental fees for such parking zone spaces, and a rental permit therefor shall be obtained from the City Clerk designating the spaces and rental, and the Commission shall obtain and place in such rental parking zone areas appropriate signs informing the public of such areas. Any unauthorized vehicles in such rental zones shall be removed by the City police, and the penalty for violating this paragraph shall be $10, together with the costs of removal of the vehicle. Twenty four hour parking shall be allowed, except as provided for maintenance and snow removal in sec. 7.05(1) and (2) of this chapter. 
(m)  Other Parking Regulations Apply. This subsection shall be deemed to be in addition and supplementary to and not in conflict with, nor a repeal of, prior or existing ordinances of the City, but shall be an additional provision for the regulation of traffic and parking in those zones provided for herein. 
(n)  Parking on Crystal Court . (Cr. Ord. #23-95) 
1.  No person shall park a motor vehicle on the south side of Crystal Court between the hours of 7:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. 
2.  No person shall park a motor vehicle on the north side of Crystal Court for a period of time in excess of 2 hours between the hours of 7:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. 
(5)  MISCELLANEOUS PARKING RESTRICTIONS. 
(a)  Street Maintenance. Whenever it is necessary to clear or repair a City roadway or any part thereof, the Street Department shall post such highways or parts thereof with signs bearing the words "No Parking-Street Maintenance Work." Such signs shall be erected at least 2 hours prior to the time that street maintenance work is to be commenced. No person shall park a motor vehicle in violation of such signs. 
(b)  Parking in Driveways. No person shall park or leave standing any motor vehicle in any private driveway without the permission of the owner or lessee of the property upon which such driveway is located, whether or not such driveway is posted to limit or restrict parking. 
(c)  Parking Heavy Vehicles in Residential District. No operator of a motor truck, truck-tractor, trailer or semi-trailer or any other vehicle or combination of vehicles other than motor buses weighing more than 6,000 pounds shall park such vehicle on any highway other than a routed State trunk highway in any residential district, except for such time as is reasonably necessary to facilitate the loading or unloading of the vehicle. 
(d)  Night Parking Restrictions. When signs have been erected at or reasonably near the corporate limits as provided in §349.13, Wis. Stats., no person shall park any vehicle for a period of time longer than 30 minutes between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M. 
(e)  Emergency Vehicle Parking . (Cr. Ord. #25-00) On the south side of Union Street, between Washington Street and the alley, parking shall be restricted to authorized emergency vehicles only, as indicated by official traffic signs. 
(6)  UNLAWFUL REMOVAL OF PARKING CITATIONS. No person other than the owner or operator thereof shall remove a City parking ticket from a motor vehicle. 
(7)  REMOVAL OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES. (Am. Ord. #8-99) Any vehicle parked or left standing upon a highway, street or alley or other public grounds in violation of any of the provisions of this section or sec. 7.01 of this chapter is declared to be a hazard to traffic and public safety. Such vehicle shall be removed by the operator, upon request of any police officer, to a position where parking, stopping or standing is not prohibited. Any police officer, after issuing a citation for illegal parking, stopping or standing of an unattended vehicle in violation of this chapter, is authorized to remove such vehicle to a position where parking is not prohibited. The officer may order a motor carrier holding a permit to perform vehicle towing services, a licensed motor vehicle salvage dealer or a licensed motor vehicle dealer who performs vehicle towing services to remove and store such vehicle in any storage garage or rental parking grounds or any facility of the person providing the towing services. In addition to other penalties provided by sec. 7.16 of this chapter, the owner or operator of a vehicle so removed shall pay the cost of towing and storage. The owner of the vehicle removed shall pay the reasonable charges for moving or towing or any storage involved; the amount the City charges the owner shall not exceed $55 for towing or moving and $15 per day for storage. These charges may be changed by the Council by subsequent ordinance, resolution or order. 
(8)  REGISTRATION RECORD OF VEHICLE AS EVIDENCE. When any vehicle is found upon a street or highway in violation of any provision of this chapter regulating the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles and the identity of the operator cannot be determined, the owner, as shown by the ownership registration of the vehicle supplied by the Wisconsin Department of transportation or a comparable authority of any other state, shall be subject to the appropriate penalty. 
(9)  PENALTIES. (Cr. Ord. #11-97; Rep. & Recr. Ord. #8-00) 
(a)  Penalties, Nonmoving Violations (Am. Ord. #08-16(2016)). Any violations of the parking regulations may be enforced by the issuance of a parking ticket. The police officer or enforcement officer shall attach to the vehicle parking in violation of this section a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle had been parked in violation of a provision of this section. The forfeitures shall be paid within 7 days of issuance and are as follows: 
1.  Overtime Parking . 
a.  First Offense: $5. 
b.  Second Offense Same Day: $12. 
c.  Third Offense Same Day: $15. 
2.  Other Offenses . 
a.  For private property, double parking, blocking alley, night parking restrictions, snow removal, fire hydrant, no parking zone, wrong side, blocking sidewalk or any other miscellaneous violation of these regulations, $15. 
b.  For parking in an area reserved for handicapped, disabled or other violations related to handicapped parking areas, the forfeiture is $75 and a parking ticket may be used to enforce these regulations. 
All forfeitures are doubled if not paid within 7 days of issuance. A person who has been issued a parking ticket may request a hearing regarding such violation by providing written notice to the City police within 10 days of issuance. The person then shall be issued a summons and citation for a violation of this section, subject to sec. 7.01 and 25.04(1) of this Code. When a timely request for a hearing is not filed, the ticket shall be presumed to be uncontested. Any ticket not paid within 10 days is subject to sec. 25.04(1) of this Code and par. (b) below relating to suspension of vehicle registration. 
(b)  Suspension of Vehicle Registration. (Am. Ord. #16-05) Pursuant to the provisions of §345.28(4), Wis. Stats., the City elects to participate in the nonmoving traffic violation and registration program, administered by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation, and pay the costs established by the Department under §85.13, Wis. Stats. A fee of $25 shall be assessed against the person violating the nonmoving traffic ordinances for the cost of administering the traffic violation and registration program. Pursuant to §345.28(4), Wis. Stats., the City may request the Department to suspend the registration of the vehicle involved or refuse registration of any vehicle owned by the person charged with a nonmoving traffic violation, who has failed to pay the applicable forfeiture, or otherwise lawfully respond to a citation. The Chief of Police shall be responsible for complying with the requirements of §345.28, Wis. Stats. 
7.06 - ABANDONED VEHICLES . 
(1)  ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES PROHIBITED. No person shall abandon any vehicle unattended within the City for such time and under such circumstances as to cause the vehicle to reasonably appear to be abandoned. 
(2)  DEFINITION. As used in this section, "vehicle" means a motor vehicle, trailer, semi-trailer or mobile home, as defined in sec. 7.01 of this chapter, whether or not such vehicle is registered under Ch. 341, Wis. Stats. 
(3)  PRESUMPTION OF ABANDONMENT. Any vehicle left unattended for more than 24 hours on any public street or grounds, or on private property where parking is prohibited, limited or restricted, without the permission of the owner or lessee, is deemed abandoned and constitutes a public nuisance; provided that the vehicle shall not be deemed abandoned under this section if left unattended on private property out of public view by permission of the owner or lessee. 
(4)  EXCEPTIONS. (Am. Ord. #2-89) This section shall not apply to a vehicle in an enclosed building, a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner authorized by the City, or a vehicle parked in a paid lot or parking space. 
(5)  REMOVAL AND IMPOUNDMENT OR SALE. Any vehicle found abandoned in violation of this chapter shall be impounded by the Police Department until lawfully claimed or disposed of as provided in this section. If the Chief of Police or his/her duly authorized representative determines that towing costs and storage charges for 10 days, as provided in sub. (6) below, would exceed the value of the vehicle, the vehicle may be junked or sold prior to the expiration of the impoundment period upon determination by the Chief of Police that the vehicle is not wanted for evidence or any other reason, provided that vehicles in excess of 19 model years of age shall be sold or disposed of only by auction sale or sealed bid, in accordance with sub. (8) below. 
(6)  MINIMUM IMPOUNDMENT PERIOD. The minimum period of impoundment or storage of a vehicle found in violation of this section shall be 10 days. 
(7)  NOTICE TO OWNER. The police officer removing or causing the removal of any vehicle found in violation of this section shall immediately notify the Chief of Police of the abandonment and location of the impounded vehicle, and shall, within 10 days thereafter, notify the owner and lienholders of record, by certified mail, of the impoundment and of their right to reclaim the vehicle. The notice shall set forth the information contained in §342.40(3), Wis. Stats., and shall state that the failure of the owner or lienholders to exercise their right to reclaim the vehicle shall be deemed a waiver of all right, title and interest in the vehicle and a consent to sale of the vehicle. 
(8)  SALE. Each retained vehicle not reclaimed by the owner or lienholder may be disposed of by sealed bid or auction sale as provided in §342.40(3), Wis. Stats. 
(9)  SALE TO BAR CLAIMS AGAINST VEHICLE. The sale of a motor vehicle under the provisions of this section shall forever bar all prior claims thereto and interest therein, except as hereinafter provided. 
(10)  PURCHASER TO REMOVE VEHICLE. (Am. Ord. #8-99) The purchaser of any vehicle on sealed bid or auction sale, under sub. (7) above, shall have 10 days to remove the vehicle from the storage area upon payment of a storage fee of $15 for each day the vehicle has remained in storage after the second business day subsequent to the sale date. Ten days after the sale, the purchaser shall forfeit all interest in the vehicle and the vehicle shall be deemed to be abandoned and may be again sold. 
(11)  REQUEST FOR LIST. Any listing of vehicles to be sold, pursuant to this section, shall be made available by the City Clerk to any interested person or organization who makes a written request therefor for a fee of $5. 
(12)  NOTICE TO DEPARTMENT. Within 5 days after sale or disposition of a vehicle under this section, the City Clerk shall advise the Wisconsin Department of Transportation of such sale or disposition on a form supplied by the Department. 
(13)  OWNER MAY FILE. At any time within 2 years after the sale of a motor vehicle, as provided herein, any person claiming ownership of such motor vehicle or a financial interest therein may present a claim to the Council setting forth such facts as are necessary to establish such ownership or interest, and that the failure of the claimant to reclaim the vehicle prior to sale was not the result of the neglect or fault of claimant. If the Council is satisfied as to the justice of such claim, it may allow the same, but in no case shall the amount allowed exceed the sum paid into the City Treasury as the result of the sale of such motor vehicle, nor the amount of interest of the claimant therein. 
(14)  EXEMPTION. Any owner or person operating a registered vehicle which shall become disabled or inoperative for any reason, and who shall be unable to cause removal of such vehicle from any alley, street, highway or public place not otherwise regulated as a restricted parking, stopping or standing zone, shall, within 12 hours of such occurrence, notify the Police Department of the location of the vehicle and shall transfer and deliver clear title for said vehicle to the City together with a fee of $25 to offset the cost of towing and junking charges and shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. When so requested by the owner or person in charge of a vehicle, the Chief of police shall be authorized to order such vehicle removed and junked directly from the scene of disablement by the Department of Public Works or the contractor engaged by the City for towing of disabled vehicles. The provisions of sub. (11) above shall apply to any vehicle removed under this subsection. 
(15)  OWNER RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPOUNDMENT AND DISPOSAL COSTS. (Cr. Ord. #8-99) The owner of any abandoned vehicle, except a stolen vehicle, is responsible for the abandonment and all costs of impounding and disposing of the vehicle. Costs not recovered from the sale of the vehicle may be recovered in a civil action by the City against the owner. The amount the City charges the owner shall not exceed $55 for towing or moving and $15 per day for storage. These charges may be changed by the Council by subsequent ordinance, resolution or order. 
7.07 - ACCIDENT REPORTS . 
(1)  OPERATORS TO FILE. (Am. Ord. #3-89) The operator of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to, or death of, any person, any damage to State-or other government-owned property, except a State-or other government-owned vehicle, to an apparent total extent of $200 or more or total damage to property owned by any one person or to a State-or other government-owned vehicle to an apparent extent of $500 or more shall, within 10 days after such accident, file with the City law enforcement department a copy of the report required by §346.70, Wis. Stats. 
(2)  REPORTS CONFIDENTIAL. Accident reports filed under this section shall be for the confidential use of the department and shall not be open to public inspection, except as permitted by §346.73, Wis. Stats. Such reports shall not be used as evidence in any trial or proceeding. 
7.08 - DISORDERLY CONDUCT WITH A MOTOR VEHICLE . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #07-04) 
(1)  No person in a motor vehicle, shall, in a private or public place, engage in disorderly conduct under circumstances in which such conduct tends to cause or provoke a disturbance. 
(2)  Disorderly conduct includes, but is not limited to: 
(a)  Unnecessary and annoying noises made with a motor vehicle, by squealing tires, by excessive acceleration of the engine, or by emitting unnecessary and loud muffler noises. 
(b)  Endangering the safety of his/her own person or property or the safety of another's person or property by the operation of a motor vehicle. 
(c)  Conduct done with no apparent reason or intent other than to intentionally annoy another. 
(d)  Using the vehicle horn, other than as a reasonable warning, or making any unnecessary or unreasonable loud or harsh sounds by means of a horn or other warning device. 
(e)  Loud or unnecessary noises or vibrations of any kind. 
(3)  A "motor vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, an automobile, truck, motorcycle, ATV, snowmobile and other over-the-land vehicles. 
7.09 - SCHOOL BUS WARNING LIGHTS . (Am. Ord. #17-10) 
Notwithstanding the provisions of §346.48(2)(b)2., Wis. Stats., adopted by reference in sec. 7.01 of this chapter to the contrary, school bus operators shall use flashing red warning lights in residential and business districts when pupils or other authorized passengers are to be loaded or unloaded at any location. 
7.10 - PARKING DURING SNOWSTORM EMERGENCY . 
(1)  EMERGENCY DECLARATIONS. (Am. Ord. #13-99) The Council hereby declares that an emergency exists in the City whenever a snowfall during any period of 24 hours or less reaches a depth of 3 inches or more, as reported by the U.S. Department of Commerce Weather Service. Such emergency is declared to be a serious public hazard impairing transportation and public health, safety and welfare until such time as snow removal operations have been declared completed by the Director of Public Works. 
(2)  PARKING REGULATIONS DURING SNOW EMERGENCIES. Whenever an emergency exists and the Director of Public Works shall have caused announcement thereof to be made by the radio stations whose normal operating range covers the City, no person shall park, or suffer to be parked, any vehicle of any kind or description in an area marked by temporary "No Parking" signs or between the hours of 10:00 P.M. and 6:00 A.M., inclusive, upon any street in the City; provided that, notwithstanding such emergency restrictions, vehicles may be parked for a period of time not longer than 3 minutes for actually loading or unloading of passengers, or 30 minutes for actually loading or unloading of property, and provided further that no other regulation restricting parking as to place, time or manner is violated thereby. 
(3)  AUTHORIZATION OF ERECTION OF NO PARKING SIGNS. Pursuant to the provisions of §166.23, Wis. Stats., the Director of Public Works is authorized to erect temporary "No Parking" signs during the existence of an emergency created by a snowstorm or excessive snowfall which impairs or prevents the full use of any highway, street or roadway for transportation. 
(4)  SNOW TOW-AWAY ZONES. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #13-99) The Director of Public Works is hereby authorized to cause the towing away of vehicles parked in violation of this section. The owner of the vehicle removed shall pay the reasonable charges for moving or towing or any storage involved; the amount the City charges the owner shall not exceed $55 for towing or moving and $15 per day for storage. These charges may be changed by the Council by subsequent ordinance, resolution or order. Also, the owner of the vehicle shall be subject to prosecution and penalty, as provided in secs. 7.16 and 7.17 of this chapter. 
(5)  PENALTY. (Am. Ord. #13-99) Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, any person violating the provisions of this section shall forfeit not less than $10 nor more than $200 plus any applicable assessments and court costs and, upon failure to pay any forfeiture, assessment and court costs imposed, the court shall order imprisonment or suspension of operating privileges or any other penalty permitted by law for the nonpayment of forfeitures. The basic forfeiture for a first offense shall be $150 plus costs. However, any person who provides proof to the issuing agency that he/she has paid the storage and towing charges prior to the due date of the forfeiture shall have the forfeiture reduced to $10 plus costs. 
7.11 - TRAFFIC AND PARKING REGULATIONS ON SCHOOL DISTRICT GROUNDS . 
Pursuant to the provisions of §118.105, Wis. Stats., the following regulations shall apply to the grounds of the Waupaca School District located within the City. 
(1)  PARKING. All parking on grounds of the Waupaca School District from 7:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. shall be by permit only and shall be restricted to areas designated for parking by the School Board. When signs are erected by the School Board giving notice of such restrictions, no person shall park a motor vehicle in an area other than one for which he/she shall have been issued a permit nor without displaying a valid permit. All authorized visitors shall park only in areas designated and signed for visitor parking. 
(2)  SPEED LIMITS. No person shall at any time operate a motor vehicle upon the Waupaca School District grounds at a speed in excess of 5 miles per hour. 
(3)  VEHICLES PROHIBITED AT SPECIFIED TIMES. No person shall at any time operate a motor vehicle, other than a school bus, in or upon any drive designated for buses only by sign during the hours of 7:30 A.M. to 9:00 A.M. and during the hours of 3:00 P.M. to 4:30 P.M. on any week day during the months school is in session. 
(4)  ONE WAY TRAFFIC. No person shall operate a motor vehicle contrary to the one way traffic signs posted on any school drive. 
7.12 - OPERATION AND PARKING OF MOTOR VEHICLES IN PUBLIC PARKING LOTS . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #24-96) 
(1)  UNLICENSED OPERATORS PROHIBITED. No person who does not hold a valid operator's license shall operate a vehicle in any public parking lot or in any private parking lot held out for the use of parking for the general public 
(2)  TRAFFIC REGULATIONS APPLICABLE. All provisions of sec. 7.01 of this chapter and of the Wisconsin statutes and laws incorporated herein by reference shall be applicable on any public parking lot and on any private parking lot held out for use of the general public for parking or vehicular travel. 
(3)  PARKING REGULATIONS. (Am. Ord. #03-14) 
(a)  The existing municipal parking lots are hereby numbered and located as follows: 
1.  Lot One. Southwest corner of South Washington Street and East Union Street AND the Southeast corner of South Franklin Street and East Union Street. 
2.  Lot Two. Surface lot located at 209 West Fulton Street. 
3.  Lot Three. Southeast corner of North Washington Street and Granite Street. 
4.  Lot Four. Rotary Riverview Park (east of North Main Street along Cooper Street). 
5.  Lot Five. City Hall. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle in parking lots numbered one, 3 or 4 between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M. unless the operator has obtained and properly displayed a valid City overnight parking permit. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle in parking lots 2 or 5 between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M. 
(d)  Overnight Parking Permits. (Am. Ord. #8-97; #27-05) Overnight parking permits for municipal parking lots shall be issued by the City Clerk. Permits shall be issued on October 1 of each year and expire on September 30 of the next year. The annual permit fee commencing October 1, 2006, shall be $72. Commencing October 1, 2007, and thereafter, the annual permit fee shall be $120. No prorated permit fee shall be permitted. The permit must be displayed in the vehicle, as required by the permit application, so that it is plainly visible from outside the motor vehicle. The permit fee is nonrefundable. The parking permit may be transferred to another person for use on a different vehicle provided the following conditions are met: 
1.  The original permit must be removed from the window of the vehicle and all remaining parts of the original permit must be surrendered to the City Clerk's office. 
2.  A $2 transfer fee shall be paid to the Clerk's office and a transfer form shall be completed and signed by the original permit holder and the transferee. 
3.  A permit application shall be completed by the transferee. A new permit shall then be issued to the transferee which shall be valid for the remaining portion of the permit year. 
(e)  License Requirements. No overnight parking permit shall be issued unless the applicant has a valid driver's license, the motor vehicle is currently registered and licensed and the motor vehicle is operable. No overnight parking permits shall be issued to any vehicle deemed by the Chief of Police or the Director of Public Works to be too large to be parked safely in a single parking stall. 
(f)  As a condition to the issuance of an overnight parking permit, the owner shall agree to the following requirements: 
1.  Upon verbal request by the City, the owner of the vehicle shall have 2 hours to remove the vehicle from the City parking lot to allow for snow removal services to be performed. 
2.  Any owner who fails to remove his/her vehicle within said 2-hour time period shall be responsible for and agrees to pay the City for all towing charges incurred by the City. 
3.  Any motor vehicle that uses any City lot may not remain parked for more than one week without being operated outside the lot. 
4.  Continual storage of a motor vehicle in any City lot for more than one week is prohibited and, upon 24-hour written notification on the vehicle by the City, will be towed from the lot if not removed by the owner. 
5.  All expenses incurred by the City for moving, towing or storage services shall be reimbursed to the City by the vehicle owner. The amount the City charges the owner shall not exceed $55 for towing or moving and $15 per day for storage. These charges may be changed by the Council by subsequent ordinance, resolution or order. (Am. Ord. #8-99) 
(g)  The Police Chief and the Director of Public Works or their designees shall administer the permit system established by this subsection and shall make any determinations regarding compliance and the applicability of this subsection. 
(h)  This subsection does not apply to any City parking lots which are leased to private entities. The terms and conditions of said lease control those parking lots. 
(i)  Penalty. (Am. Ord. #8-99) Any person who shall violate any provision of this subsection shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $50 nor more than $200, together with any assessments and court costs, and shall be responsible to reimburse the City for any moving, towing or storage charges. However, any person who provides proof to the issuing agency that he/she has paid the moving, towing and storage charges prior to the due date for the forfeiture shall have the forfeiture reduced to $10 plus costs. 
(4)  All of the provisions of sec. 7.06 of this chapter prohibiting abandoned vehicles apply to City-owned parking lots. All of the provisions of sec. 7.10 of this chapter prohibiting parking during snow emergencies apply to City-owned parking lots in addition to the regulations set forth in sub. (3)(f) above. 
(5)  The Chief of Police or the Director of Public Works or their respective designees are hereby authorized to post signs on the City-owned parking lots advising the public of these prohibitions. 
(6)  No person may skateboard or rollerblade in the City Hall parking lot (Lot 5). (Am. Ord. #1-98) 
7.13 - OBSTRUCTION OF RAILROAD CROSSINGS . 
(1)  TIME LIMITATIONS. It shall be unlawful to stop any railroad train, locomotive or railroad car upon or across any highway or street crossing or to cause obstruction of vehicular traffic on public streets at such crossing by the stopping, leave standing, switching or otherwise maintaining constant railway use at such crossing longer than 5 continuous minutes, or for more than 7 minutes out of any 12 continuous minutes. 
(2)  PENALTY. Either the owner or any conductor, engineer, switchman, brakeman or other employee or agent in charge of, or otherwise responsible for, such offending railroad locomotive or car who shall violate the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, pay the City a forfeiture of not less than $50 nor more than $150 for each such violation, and a violation for each 12-minute period shall constitute a separate offense, plus the costs of prosecution, and, in default of payment, shall be imprisoned not less than 5 days nor more than 15 days in the County jail.
