7.15 - WAUPACA MUNICIPAL AIRPORT; REGULATION OF VEHICULAR AND PEDESTRIAN TRAFFIC . 
(1)  DEFINITIONS. As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and phrases used shall be defined as follows: 
(a)  Airport. The Waupaca Municipal Airport. 
(b)  Taxiway. An area designated or used solely for the taxiing of aircraft, except apron areas. 
(c)  Runway. Any hard surfaced area used and designed for the taking off and landing of aircraft. 
(d)  Landing Strip. Any area designed and used for the landing and taking off of aircraft. 
(e)  Apron. An area adjacent to the administrative and business hangar sections of the airport designed and used solely for the parking and servicing of aircraft. 
(f)  Tie-Down. An area designed and used for the parking and tying down and storage of aircraft. 
(g)  Vehicle. Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway. 
(h)  Emergency Equipment. Ambulances, crash rescue and firefighting apparatus and such other equipment as the Council may designate as necessary to safeguard airport runways, taxiways, ramps, buildings and other property. 
(i)  Service, Maintenance and Construction Equipment. Equipment normally operated by the City and/or the Civil Aeronautics Administration on landing areas, runways, taxiways and peripheral roads for the servicing, maintenance and construction of airport facilities and services. This definition shall include equipment owned and operated by a contractor performing work on the airport under a contractual agreement with the City. 
(2)  REGULATION OF VEHICULAR AND PEDESTRIAN TRAFFIC. 
(a)  Operation of Vehicles on Runways, Taxiways and Ramps . No privately owned vehicle shall enter, be driven upon, or operated upon any airport runway, taxiway, ramp, tie-down area or any area posted by signs prohibiting the entrance thereon. The provisions of this section shall not apply to emergency equipment or service, or maintenance and construction equipment when engaged in performing official duties. Aircraft owners shall be excluded from the provisions of this section relating to tie-down areas when necessary to reach their own aircraft, but in doing so they shall not pass over any runway, taxiway or ramp and shall proceed through said tie-down area at a speed not to exceed 10 miles per hour. They shall not at any time park a vehicle on any area used for the movement of aircraft. 
(b)  Speed of Vehicles . No vehicle shall be driven upon any road within the perimeter of the Waupaca Municipal Airport or upon other Airport areas in excess of the speed limit posted at the entrance of said Airport or within the boundaries thereof if more than one speed limit is applicable, nor shall the driver of any vehicle fail to adhere to any sign posted to regulate vehicular traffic on or about the Waupaca Municipal Airport for the safety of the public. 
(c)  Pedestrian Traffic on Airport . No pedestrian shall be allowed beyond the administration area onto the apron or aircraft tie down area unless for the purpose of embarking on or disembarking from an aircraft, or unless authorized by the Airport Manager. Pedestrian traffic is prohibited in the runway and outlying area of the Airport, except for those employes of the City, County, State or Federal governments, or contractors engaged in Airport construction or maintenance work. 
7.151 - PUBLIC WORKS SHORT TERM WORK SITES . (Cr. Ord. #14-95) 
Public Works Department maintenance and minor construction operations lasting 60 minutes or less shall be governed by this section. All City employees shall comply with the requirements of §§347.23 and 347.27, Wis. Stats., relating to lighting on highway maintenance equipment. Traffic cones and a minimum of one warning sign shall be used at all work sites. They shall be placed in positions conducive to the safety of the traveling public, pedestrians and workers. This section sets forth minimum standards for normal short term work sites, and additional protection shall be provided when special complexities and hazards exist. 
7.152 - COMPRESSION BRAKES PROHIBITED . (Cr. Ord. #22-00) 
(1)  No person shall use motor vehicle brakes within the City limits which are in any way activated or operated by the compression of the engine of any such motor vehicle or any unit or part thereof. (This system of braking is commonly referred to as compression braking or a "jake brake".) 
(2)  The Director of Public Works is authorized and directed to post appropriate signs consistent with the provisions of this section. 
(3)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall have committed a traffic offense and a penalty shall be imposed as provided in sec. 25.04 of this Code. 
7.16 - PENALTIES . 
(1)  FORFEITURE PENALTY AND ASSESSMENTS. (Am. Ord. #7-88) The penalty and assessments for violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a forfeiture as hereinafter provided, together with the costs of prosecution and the penalty assessments imposed by §165.87(2)(a), Wis. Stats., the jail assessment imposed by §53.46, Wis. Stats., and the automation fee imposed by §814.635, Wis. Stats., where applicable. Payment of the judgment may be suspended by the sentencing judge for not more than 60 days. Any person who shall fail to pay the amount of the forfeiture, costs of prosecution and penalty imposed for violation of any provision of this chapter may, upon order of the court entering judgment therefor and having jurisdiction of the case, be imprisoned until such forfeiture, costs and assessment are paid, but not exceeding 90 days. 
(2)  OTHER SANCTIONS. Nothing herein shall preclude or affect the power of the sentencing court to exercise additional authorities granted by the Wisconsin statutes to suspend or revoke the operating privileges of the defendant or to order the defendant to submit to assessment and rehabilitation or attend traffic safety school in addition to payment of a monetary penalty or in lieu of imprisonment. 
(3)  FORFEITURES FOR UNIFORM TRAFFIC OFFENSES. Forfeitures for violations of any traffic regulation set forth in the Wisconsin statutes adopted by reference in sec. 7.01 of this chapter shall conform to the forfeiture penalty permitted to be imposed for violations of the comparable State statute, including any variations or increases for subsequent offenses; provided, however, that this subsection shall not permit prosecution under this chapter of any offense for which an imprisonment penalty or fine may be imposed upon the defendant. 
(4)  FORFEITURES FOR PARKING VIOLATIONS. 
(a)  Forfeitures For Uniform State-Wide Parking, Stopping and Standing Offenses . Minimum and maximum forfeitures for violation of the offenses described in §§346.51 to 346.55, Wis. Stats., adopted by reference in sec. 7.01 of this chapter, shall be as follows:

7.17 ENFORCEMENT . 
This chapter shall be enforced in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Wisconsin Statutes and this section. 
(1)  APPLICABLE COURT PROCEDURES. Except as otherwise specifically provided by the laws of the State or the provisions of this chapter, the traffic regulations in this chapter shall be enforced in the Circuit Court of Waupaca County in accordance with the provisions of §§66.0114 and 346.20(2)(a) and Ch. 299, Wis. Stats. 
(2)  CITATIONS. 
a.  Uniform Citation and Complaint . The Wisconsin Uniform Traffic Citation and Complaint described and defined in the Wisconsin statutes shall be used for enforcement of all provisions of this chapter, except those provisions which describe or define nonmoving traffic violations and violations of §§346.71 through 346.73, Wis. Stats. Violations of §§346.71 through 346.73 shall be reported to the District Attorney and the Wisconsin Uniform Traffic Citation shall not be used in such cases, except upon written request of the District Attorney. 
(b)  Parking Citations . The City Attorney shall recommend a citation for use in enforcing the nonmoving traffic offenses in this chapter. When approved by the Council, such citation shall be used for enforcement of nonmoving traffic regulations created or adopted by this chapter, including violations of nonmoving traffic regulations defined and described in the Wisconsin statutes, adopted by reference in sec. 7.01 of this chapter and all provisions of secs. 7.05 and 7.06 of this chapter. The citation for nonmoving traffic violations shall contain a notice that the person cited may discharge the forfeiture for violation of a nonmoving traffic regulation and penalty thereof by complying with sub. (3)(b) below. Nonmoving traffic citations may be issued by law enforcement officers or by civilian employees of the Police Department. 
(3)  DEPOSITS AND STIPULATIONS. 
(a)  Uniform Traffic Offenses . 
1.  Who May Make. Persons arrested or cited for violation of moving traffic offenses created by this chapter shall be permitted to make deposits and stipulations of no contest or released by the arresting officer in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Wisconsin statutes. 
2.  Delivery or Mailing of Deposit and Stipulation. The deposit and stipulation shall be delivered personally by the person cited or mailed to Police Department headquarters. 
3.  Receipt Required. The official or person receiving the deposit shall furnish and deliver or mail an original receipt for such deposit to the alleged violator and shall deliver the deposit and stipulation and a copy of the receipt within 3 days to the Clerk of Courts. 
(b)  Nonmoving Traffic Offenses . 
1.  Direct Payment of Penalty Permitted. Except for overtime parking at meters, as provided in sec. 7.05(4) of this chapter, persons cited for violation of nonmoving traffic offenses described and defined in this chapter may discharge the penalty thereof and avoid court prosecution by forwarding, within 3 days of the issuance of the citation, to the Police Department the minimum penalty specified for the violation. If not so forwarded, the penalty may be discharged by forwarding within 10 days of the date of the citation to the above named office double the amount of the minimum penalty specified. When payment is made, as provided in this paragraph, no court costs shall be charged. 
2.  Court Prosecution. If the alleged violator does not deliver or mail a deposit, as provided in subpar. 1. above, within 10 days of the date of the citation, the Chief of Police shall forward a copy of the citation to the City Attorney for prosecution, pursuant to law. 
3.  Deposits Returned to City Clerk. (Am. Ord. #01-04) Officers receiving deposits for nonmoving traffic violations under this subsection shall pay over such deposits to the City Clerk within 3 days of receipt. Such payment shall be accompanied by an itemized statement for each deposit of the offense charged and the name of the depositor. 
7.18 - REFERENCES TO WISCONSIN STATUTES . 
(1)  STATUTES SPECIFICALLY INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE. Whenever this chapter incorporates by reference specific sections of the Wisconsin Statutes, such references shall mean the Wisconsin Statutes of 1977, as from time to time amended, repealed or modified by the Wisconsin Legislature. 
(2)  GENERAL REFERENCES. General references in this chapter to Wisconsin statutory sections or chapters describing or defining procedures or authority for enactment or enforcement of local traffic regulations shall be deemed to refer to the most recent enactments of the Wisconsin Legislature describing or defining such procedures or authorities. 
7.19 - WEIGHT RESTRICTION . (Cr. Ord. #05-07) 
No person, whether operating under a permit or otherwise, shall operate a vehicle in violation of special weight limitations imposed by local authorities on the bridge(s) designated as follows when signs have been erected as required by §349.16(2), Wis. Stats. The compliance with regard to the modification, designation, and signing of the bridge will be in accordance with applicable Wisconsin Statutes. 
Bridge No. P-68-0714 (Shearer Street) over the Waupaca River in the City of Waupaca, Wisconsin, be posted with a 45-ton weight limit.

8.01 - OFFICIAL MAP . 
(1)  INTENT. It is the intent of the Council to establish an Official Map for the purpose of serving and promoting the public health, safety, convenience, economy, orderliness and general welfare of the community; to further the orderly layout and use of land; to stabilize the location of real property boundary lines; to insure proper legal descriptions and proper monumenting of land; to facilitate adequate provision for transportation, parks, playgrounds and storm water drainage; and to facilitate the further subdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land. 
(2)  OFFICIAL MAP. (Am. Ord. #6-94) The Official Map shall show the location and extent of all platted and existing streets, highways, parkways, parks and playgrounds within the City as heretofore laid out, adopted and established by law. There is hereby established, as the Official Map of the City, the Map dated March 1, 1994, recorded in the office of the Register of Deeds for Waupaca County. All notations, references and other information shown thereon shall be as much a part of this section as though the matters and information thereon were fully described herein. 
(3)  CHANGES AND ADDITIONS. 
(a)  The Council may change or add to the Official Map so as to establish the exterior lines of, widen, narrow, extend or close any platted, existing, proposed or planned streets, highways, parkways, parks or playgrounds. 
(b)  The Council shall refer any change or addition to the Official Map to the Plan Commission for review and report thereon prior to adoption. The Plan Commission shall report their recommendation to the Council within 60 days. 
(c)  A public hearing of parties in interest and citizens before the Council shall be required before any changes or additions to the Official Map are effective. At least 15 days' notice of said hearing shall be required by publication. 
(d)  Changes and additions made by duly approved subdivision plats shall not require a public hearing if the changes or additions do not affect any land outside the area being platted. 
(4)  BUILDING PERMITS. For the purpose of preserving the integrity of the Official Map, a building permit shall be required for any structure or part thereof that shall hereafter be located, erected, moved, reconstructed, extended, enlarged, converted or structurally altered. No permit shall hereafter be issued for any building in the bed of any existing or proposed street, highway or parkway shown on the Official Map. No permit for the erection of any building shall be issued unless a street, highway or parkway giving access to such proposed structure has been duly placed on this Map. No damages shall be allowed for the taking by any governmental agency for street, highway and parkway purposes, any building erected in violation of this section. 
(5)  MUNICIPAL IMPROVEMENTS. No public sewer or other municipal street utility or improvement shall be constructed in any street, highway or parkway within the City until such street, highway or parkway is duly placed on the Official Map. 
(6)  APPEALS. The Board of Zoning Appeals shall have the power to review any administrative decision of the Building Inspector to deny a permit for the erection of a structure under this section and to grant relief from the requirements of this section under the provisions of §62.23(6)(d), (f) and (g), Wis. Stats. 
(7)  CERTIFIED COPY OF MAP. There shall be a certified copy of the Official Map. The certified copy shall be kept in the office of the City Clerk and shall be available for inspection by any interested person during regular office hours. The certified copy shall bear on its face a certification that it is a true copy of the Official Map described in and accompanying this section and shall show the date of adoption of this section and shall be signed by the Mayor and countersigned by the Clerk. Thereafter no change or addition to such Official Map shall become effective until it shall have been indicated by the appropriate certification on the aforesaid certified copy of the Official Map and a certificate placed thereon or attached thereto bearing the number and date of adoption of the amending ordinance. The certificate shall be signed by the Mayor and countersigned by the City Clerk. 
(8)  MAP TO BE FILED WITH REGISTER OF DEEDS. The City Clerk shall be responsible immediately upon adoption of the Official Map or any amendment thereto for recording a true copy of the amended Official Map with the Register of Deeds of Waupaca County. 
(9)  ENFORCEMENT. It shall be the duty of the Building Inspector and the Chief of Police to enforce the provisions of this section. 
8.02 - OFFICIAL MAP, AMENDMENTS . 
Ordinance numbers 12-92, 17-92, 1-93, 2-93, 3-93, 13-93, 17-93, 21-93, 16-94, 23-94, 25-94, 2-96, 6-96, 1-97, 2-97, 3-97, 10-97, 12-98, 6-99, 16-99, 18-01 (see Miscellaneous Ordinances). 
8.03 - STREET IMPROVEMENTS . 
(1)  TO BE DONE BY CITY OR BY CONTRACT. All street improvements, including all street surfacing and layout of sewer and water mains, urban gutters and sidewalks, shall be done by City forces or by contract. 
(1a)  CONSTRUCTION OR MAINTENANCE OF STREETS WITHOUT COMPETITIVE BIDDING. (Cr. Ord. #5-96) The City, upon recommendation of the Board of Public Works, may enter into contracts with Waupaca County for the construction or maintenance of streets within the City without competitive bidding. The City may also elect to directly perform any construction or maintenance of streets without competitive bidding. 
(2)  SIZE OF SEWER AND WATER MAINS. (Am. Ord. #19-04) Water mains shall be at least 8 inches in diameter and sanitary sewer mains shall be at least 8 inches in diameter. 
(3)  SEQUENCE OF IMPROVEMENTS. As a general rule, it will be the policy to install water and sewer improvements in one year and the curb, gutter and street improvements during the following year. A high-type bituminous or concrete surfacing shall not be placed on any street until curb and gutter, sewer and water with laterals, and storm sewer, where required, are in place. 
(4)  CONNECTION OF LATERALS. No private sewer or water lateral shall be connected with public sewer or water main without a permit therefor issued as directed by the Council. 
(5)  MANDATORY INSTALLATION OF LATERALS. Whenever the Council shall declare its intention to improve any street, water and sewer service laterals shall be first laid in such street at the cost of the property fronting thereon, from the sewer and water mains to the curb line on either or both sides thereof at such intervals as the City Engineer shall direct. The Board of Public Works shall annually determine the average cost of installation of sewer and water laterals and report the same to the Council. The Council shall annually, by resolution, establish such average current costs, as provided in §66.0911, Wis. Stats. Each such lateral installed shall be charged to each lot or parcel as a special tax and shall be collected as are other taxes on real estate. 
(6)  WIDTH OF STREET SURFACING. (Am. Ord. #16-93; Am. Ord. #19-04) All surfacing on streets in residential areas shall be 32 feet in width, face to face with the curbing, unless the street right of way is less than 50 feet, in which case the Council shall determine the width. Where, in the judgment of the Board of Public Works, because of exceptional circumstances or undue hardship, it is unnecessary for the minor street width to be 32 feet, a variance may be granted. The procedure set forth in sec. 18.14 of this Code (variances) shall be followed and the final action and determination shall be made by the Council. 
(7)  GUTTERS. All curbs shall have an integral 18 inch gutter. 
(8)  SIDEWALKS, PAVED SHOULDERS, PATHS AND TRAILS. (Cr. Ord. #26-04) 
(a)  The City, upon recommendation of the Board of Public Works, shall determine the need for installation of sidewalks, paved shoulders, paths or trails based on the following criteria. 
1.  Roadway vehicle volume and speed limits. 
2.  Road classification, ie collection roads. 
3.  Pedestrian and bicycle volumes. 
4.  Direct access to public place, i.e. schools, playgrounds, commercial areas, public buildings, etc. 
5.  Land uses. 
6.  Population density. 
7.  Connectivity to other sidewalks, paved shoulders, paths and trails. 
8.  Existence of a sidewalk agreement or development agreement with the City. 
(b)  If it is determined that sidewalks shall be constructed only on one side of the street, with all things being equal, it is the preference that construction shall be on the North or East side of the street. 
(c)  The cost of sidewalk construction shall be assessed to the adjacent property owner in accordance with sec. 8.04, Waupaca Municipal Code. There shall be no assessment for paved shoulders, paths or trails. Lots or parcels of land located at street intersections shall be assessed an amount based on the average width of the lots for the area. 
8.04 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS FOR STREET IMPROVEMENTS . 
(1)  SECTIONS 66.0703 and 66.0701, WIS. STATS., RESPECTIVELY, TO BE FOLLOWED. The cost of laying sanitary sewer and water mains, streets, sidewalks and curb and gutter shall be assessed against the abutting property in accordance with §§66.0703 and 66.0701, Wis. Stats., respectively. Charges for current services such as snow and ice removal, weed elimination, street sprinkling, oiling and tarring, repair of sidewalks or curb and gutter, garbage and refuse disposal, sewer service and tree care may be imposed against the property served, pursuant to §66.0627, Wis. Stats. 
(2)  EXCEPTIONS. 
(a)  Sidewalk Replacement. When sidewalks are replaced, the property owner shall be assessed 1/2 of the cost. 
(b)  Curb and Gutter Replacement. (Am. Ord. #19-04) When curb and gutter are replaced the City shall pay the entire cost. 
(c)  Corner Lots. (Am. Ord. #19-04) Lots or parcels of land located at street intersections shall be exempt, not to exceed the number of feet of the width of an average lot for the area, from special assessments if the sanitary sewer or water main is laid at the same time in both the intersecting streets on which the corner lot or parcel abuts, or if there is already a sanitary sewer or water main in one of the streets upon which the lot or parcel abuts at the time of installation of the sanitary sewer or water main for which the special assessment is made. Pursuant to §66.0703(3), Wis. Stats., the Council shall examine each such lot or parcel to determine if application of the exemption stated herein is just and reasonable under the circumstances, and, if not, the Council shall alter the exemption accordingly. 
(3)  LIMITATIONS. (Am. Ord. #19-04) The special assessment for installation of water mains shall in no case exceed the per front foot cost of installing an 8-inch water main or, in the case of a sanitary sewer, the cost of installing an 8-inch sewer. All oversized mains shall be assessed upon the property benefiting on an area basis. 
(4)  COLLECTION. All special assessments levied hereunder shall be collected pursuant to §66.0703, Wis. Stats., as determined by the Council. 
(5)  INTEREST. (Cr. Ord. #9-94) Deferred special assessments shall bear simple interest at a rate which is 2% above the City's current borrowing rate. 
8.045 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS, ALTERNATE PROCEDURE . (Cr. Ord. #4-97) 
(1)  In addition to other methods provided by law, special assessments for any public work or improvement or any current service may be levied in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Whenever the governing body shall determine that any public works or improvement or any current service shall be financed in whole or in part by special assessments levied under this section, it shall adopt a resolution specifying this intention and the time, either before or after completion of the work or improvement, when the amount of the assessments will be determined and levied, the number of annual installments, if any, in which assessments may be paid, the rate of interest to be charged on the unpaid balance and the terms on which any of the assessments may be deferred while no use of the improvement is made in connection with the property. 
(3)  The provisions of §66.0703, Wis. Stats., shall apply to special assessments levied under this section except that, when the governing body determines, by resolution, that the hearing on the assessments be held subsequent to the completion of the work or improvement or the rendering of the service, the report required by §66.0703, Wis. Stats., shall contain a statement of the final cost of the work, service or improvement in lieu of an estimate of the cost. 
(4)  Notice of the time and place of the public hearing on any special assessment proposed to be levied and notice of the final assessment and terms of payment thereof shall be given in the manner prescribed by §66.0703(7)(a) and (8)(d), Wis. Stats. 
(5)  Any special assessment levied under this section shall be a lien against the property assessed from the date of the final resolution of the governing body determining the amount of the levy. 
(6)  Any person against whose property a special assessment is levied under this section may appeal therefrom in the manner prescribed by §66.0703(12), Wis. Stats., within 40 days of the date of the final determination of the governing body. 
8.05 - STREET EXCAVATIONS. (Am. Ord. #12-15(2015)) 
(1)  PERMIT. No cut, excavation or service connection shall be made within the City of Waupaca right-of-way unless a permit is obtained from the Director of Public Works or designee. 
(2)  FEES. 
(a)  A minimum permit fee of $300 shall be charged for any disturbance made within any portion of the right-of-way as part of the permit. 
(b)  The fee shall be assessed for each cut, excavation, trench, or service connection made that disturbs any portion of the roadway, sidewalk, curbs, curb and gutter, or driveway. 
(3)  REGULATIONS FOR FILLING CUTS OR EXCAVATIONS. 
(a)  Maintain the safety of the traveling public. Control vehicle and pedestrian traffic using barricades, traffic cones or drums, warning signs, flaggers, and temporary barriers as needed. In no case shall work be performed that will cut off traffic flow completely, except by special permission of the Director of Public Works. 
(b)  All cuts or excavations made in paved areas shall be backfilled with granular material or suitable equivalent as approved by the Street Superintendent. The contractor or utility shall compact all subgrade layers with mechanical compaction equipment in layers not greater than 12 inches. Base coarse material shall match existing adjacent conditions but shall be no less than 12 inches of 11/4-inch base aggregate dense or equivalent. The contractor or utility shall compact base course layers with mechanical compaction equipment in layers not greater than 6 inches. Unsuitable excavated material shall be hauled away by the contractor or utility and no rocks or old pavement may be deposited within the backfill. Immediately after backfilling and compacting, the contractor or utility doing the work shall notify the Street Department of the completion of the backfilling. 
(c)  The contractor or utility shall replace all disturbed pavement, curbs, curb and gutter, sidewalk, and driveway aprons at its own expense no later than 7 days after backfilling. 
(d)  If a cut is made in an asphalt street, hot mix asphalt (HMA) mixture shall be placed to match the existing thickness but shall be no less than 4 inches in total thickness. HMA material shall be placed in layers not less than 1.5 inches nor greater than 3.5 inches after compaction. If HMA material is unavailable due to seasonal constraints, the contractor or utility shall place cold mix asphalt temporarily. The cold mix asphalt must be replaced, at the expense of the contractor or utility, upon availability of HMA material. 
(e)  If a cut is made in a concrete street, 8 inches of concrete of a mixture of 6 bags of cement to the cubic yard shall be placed and finished off level with and in the same manner as the existing concrete pavement. The contractor or utility shall pin all concrete work installed including sidewalk, pavement, curbs, curb and gutter, and driveways, as approved by the Street Superintendent. If the concrete is not placed within 7 days after backfilling, the Street Department shall replace the concrete and charge the contractor or utility for the cost of such replacement. 
(f)  All boulevards and lawns disturbed by the contractor or utility's operation shall be restored, immediately after backfilling has been completed. All such restoration shall be subject to the direction of the Street Superintendent relating to amount of topsoil, type and quality of grass seed, use of matting and mulching, and amount and ratio of fertilizer. All utility locate flags shall be removed by the contractor or utility after work is completed. 
(g)  All curbs, curb and gutters, sidewalks, and driveway aprons disturbed by the contractor or utility operation must be replaced with concrete of a mixture of 6 bags of cement to the cubic yard. The concrete shall be placed no later than 7 days after backfill has been completed. If not done within this period of time, the Street Department will perform the work and charge the cost thereof to the contractor or utility. Any portion of a driveway or sidewalks within driveways shall be 7 inches thick with 6 inches of 3/4-inch base aggregate dense or equivalent. All other sidewalk shall be 5 inches thick with 6 inches of 3/4-inch base aggregate dense or equivalent. All curbs and curb and gutter shall be formed and placed to match existing. 
(h)  If the replaced pavement, curbs, curb and gutter, sidewalk, or driveway apron settles or cracks within one year of the date of the permit and if failure of the replacement is due to improper backfill, compaction, or material usage; the Street Department shall replace all defective work and charge the contractor or utility for the cost of such replacement. 
8.06 - OBSTRUCTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS . 
(1)  PROHIBITED. No person shall encroach upon or in any way obstruct or encumber any street, alley, sidewalk, public grounds or land dedicated to public use, or any part thereof, or permit such encroachment or encumbrance to be placed or remain on any public way adjoining the premises of which he/she is the owner or occupant, except as provided in sub. (2) below. 
(2)  EXCEPTIONS. The prohibition of sub. (1) above shall not apply to the following: 
(a)  Trees and branches which do not extend below any point 8 feet above the sidewalk or 10 feet above a street or alley. 
(b)  Public utility encroachments duly authorized by State law or by the Council. 
(c)  Goods, wares, merchandise or fixtures being loaded or unloaded which do not extend more than 3 feet on a sidewalk, provided such goods, wares, etc., do not remain thereon for more than 3 hours. 
(d)  Racks or platforms for the display of merchandise at least 18 inches above the sidewalk and extending not more than 24 inches from the building to which attached. 
(e)  Building materials under permit from the Council which shall not obstruct more than 1/2 of the sidewalk or more than 1/3 of the traveled portion of the street, and shall not interfere with flow in the gutters. The Council shall require that any such building materials be protected by lighted and reflective barricades. (Am. Ord. #19-04) 
(f)  Goods, wares, merchandise or fixtures on the sidewalks of the blocks of Main Street between its intersection with Badger Street and Granite Street; provided, however, that there is an unencumbered space 5 feet wide on the sidewalks on the block from Badger Street to Union Street on the east side of Main Street, and provided there is an unencumbered space 7 feet wide on the sidewalks on the remaining blocks of Main Street as above set forth effective upon adoption and publication according to law. (Cr. Ord. #11-88; Am. Ord. #19-03) 
8.07 - VEHICLES LIKELY TO DAMAGE STREETS RESTRICTED . 
No vehicle having lugs or cleats on the wheels or being so heavy or so heavily loaded as to endanger the surface of streets or alleys shall be operated thereon without a permit from the Street Superintendent, which permit shall specify the route to be taken by such vehicle. He/she may require the removal from any such vehicle any flanges, cleats or other removable parts which would damage the street and may also require that planks or other sufficient protection for the streets be provided by the person operating such vehicle. 
8.08 - COASTING OR SKIING ON STREETS PROHIBITED . 
No person shall coast or ski on any of the streets or alleys of the City or attach a coasting or skiing vehicle to another vehicle to be towed on any street or alley within the City. 
8.09 - SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL . 
(1)  RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNER OR OCCUPANT. The owner or occupant of a lot or parcel abutting on a sidewalk within the City shall clear said sidewalk of snow or ice to the width of the sidewalk within 24 hours of the cessation of any snowfall. If ice forms so that it cannot be removed, such person shall keep the sidewalks sprinkled with a material which will reduce the risk to pedestrians of slipping and falling on such sidewalk. Snow not timely removed and ice not timely removed or sprinkled shall be deemed a public nuisance, as provided in sec. 10.05(13) of this Code. 
(2)  REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE BY CITY. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #7-82; Am. Ord. #19-04) In the event the owner or occupant fails to remove snow or ice in conformity with this section, the Director of Public Works may direct City employees to remove such snow and ice and charge the cost thereof as a special tax against the property. The cost shall be based on time, materials and overhead expense. 
(3)  PLOWING SNOW ONTO STREETS PROHIBITED. The owner or lessee of every lot or parcel in the City shall not by himself/herself or his/her agent push, plow or otherwise deposit snow from within his/her lot line onto the public street or alley. 
8.10 - BUILDING NUMBERING SYSTEM . 
(1)  There is hereby established a uniform system of numbering houses and buildings fronting on all streets, avenues and public ways in the City, and all houses and buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(2)  East and West Fulton Streets and their extensions shall constitute the base line for numbering along all streets running north and south, and Main Street and its extensions shall constitute the base line for numbering all streets running east and west. 
(3)  The numbering for each street shall begin at the base line. The numbers in the first block shall be from 100 to 199, the second block 200 to 299, the third block 300 to 399, etc. There shall be assigned 100 numbers to each block, square or space that would be one block or square if streets each way were so extended as to intersect each other and one number shall be assigned to each 20 feet of frontage. In blocks or equivalent space longer than 1,250 feet which is not intersected by a street, the total length of space divided by 50 shall be used to determine the feet of frontage to be assigned each number. 
(4)  All lots and houses shall be numbered with even numbers on the right side of the street, commencing at the base line, and all lots and houses shall be numbered with odd numbers on the left side of the street, commencing at the base line, each commencing with the hundred assigned to that block, and shall increase from the base line, one number for each 20 feet of frontage or fraction thereof, except as provided in sub. (3) above. Where any building has more than one door serving separate occupants, a separate number shall be assigned to each door serving a separate occupant, providing the building is 25 feet or more in width. If the building is not 25 feet or more in width, and the entrances are not that far apart, the next consecutive number shall be marked fractional. Buildings fronting on 2 or more streets shall have a number fronting on the main entrance unless other entrances serve other occupants. 
(5)  All streets not extending through to the base line shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the said street had extended to the said base line. 
(6)  BUILDING NUMBERS. 
(a)  The Council has caused a survey to be made and there is hereby assigned to each house and building located on any street, alley, highway or avenue in the City its respective number under the uniform system provided for in this section, as shown on the map attached to and made a part of this section. Within 60 days after notice by the Building Inspector, the owner, occupant or agent shall place, or cause to be placed, upon each house or building controlled by him/her the number or numbers assigned under the uniform system provided for in this section. 
(b)  The numbers shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the proper door of each building so that the number can be seen plainly from the street. Whenever any building is situated more than 50 feet from the street line, the number of such building shall be conspicuously displayed in an appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the sidewalk. 
(7)  Where only one number can be assigned to any house or building, the owner, occupant or agent of such house or building who shall desire distinctive numbers for the upper and lower portion of any such house or building, or for any part of such house or building fronting on any street, may use the suffix "A", "B", "C", etc., as may be required. 
(8)  For the purpose of facilitating correct numbering, a map showing the proper number of all lots or houses fronting upon all streets, avenues or highways shall be kept on file in the office of the Building Inspector. This map shall be open to inspection by all persons during the office hours of the Building Inspector. 
(9)  The Building Inspector shall inform any party applying therefor of the number or numbers belonging to or embraced within the limits of said lot or property, as provided in this section. In case of doubt as to the proper number to be assigned to any lot or building, the Building Inspector shall determine the number of each lot or building. 
(10)  Whenever any house, building or structure shall hereafter be erected or located in the City, it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the number so assigned upon said building as provided by this section. No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has procured from the Building Inspector the official number of the premises. 
(11)  All police officers of the City shall report the violation of any provision of this section. 
(12)  If the owner or occupant of any building required to be numbered by this section shall neglect for more than 60 days to duly attach and maintain the proper numbers of such building, the Building Inspector shall cause to be served upon such owner or occupant the notice requiring such owner or occupant to properly number the same and if he/she neglects to do so for 10 days after the serving of such notice, he/she shall be deemed to have violated this section. 
8.15 - PENALTY . 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or any order, rule or regulation made hereunder shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec. 25.04 of this Code.
