10.04 - PUBLIC NUISANCES OFFENDING MORALS AND DECENCY. 
The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby specifically declared to be public nuisances offending public morals and decency, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending public morals and decency coming within the definition of sec. 10.02 of this chapter. 
(1)  DISORDERLY HOUSES. All disorderly houses, bawdy houses, houses of ill fame, gambling houses and buildings or structures kept or resorted to for the purpose of prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse or gambling. 
(2)  GAMBLING DEVICES. All gambling devices and slot machines. 
(3)  UNLICENSED SALE OF LIQUOR AND BEER. All places where intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages are sold, possessed, stored, brewed, bottled, manufactured or rectified without a permit or license, as provided for by this Code. 
(4)  CONTINUOUS VIOLATION OF CITY ORDINANCES. Any place or premises within the City where City ordinances or State laws relating to public health, safety, peace, morals or welfare are openly, continuously, repeatedly and intentionally violated. 
(5)  ILLEGAL DRINKING. (Am. Ord. #01-14) Except as provided in sub. (6) below, the drinking of any intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages in violation of State laws and this Code, or the carrying of any open container which contains an intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverage, is prohibited in the following places: 
(a)  On private property without the owner's consent. 
(b)  On any street, roadway, alley, parking lot or sidewalk. 
(c)  On any public property in the City. 
(d)  By passengers on a commercial quadricycle as defined under §340.01(8m) Wis. Stats. 
(6)  LICENSE OR PERMIT REQUIRED FOR PREMISES PERMITTING CONSUMPTION OF FERMENTED MALT BEVERAGES (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #13-97). The prohibition relating to the drinking of fermented malt beverages in any public park, street, public place or other public area within the City, as provided in sub. (5) above, shall not apply to organizations and groups which have been issued a license or permit as follows: 
(a)  Any organization enumerated in §125.26(6), Wis. Stats., may be issued a Class "B" fermented malt beverage picnic license, pursuant to sec. 12.02(3)(c) of this Code. 
(b)  Permits may be granted by the Park and Recreation Department for a picnic or similar gathering of a bona fide fraternal, patriotic, religious, philanthropic, veterans, recreational, social or other similar groups that have been in existence for at least one year. Permits under this subsection may also be issued to groups of people related by marriage, blood or adoption. This permit authorizes the consumption and use of fermented malt beverages. Permits under this subsection shall only be issued in conjunction with the rental of a shelter as provided in City of Waupaca Municipal Code, sec. 18A.03. (Am. Ord. #02-05) 
10.05 - PUBLIC NUISANCES AFFECTING PEACE AND SAFETY . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #02-15(2015)) 
The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and safety, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances affecting public peace or safety coming within the definition of sec. 10.02: 
(1)  SIGNS, BILLBOARDS, ETC. All signs and billboards, awnings and other similar structures over or near streets, sidewalks, public grounds or places frequented by the public, so situated or constructed as to endanger the public safety. 
(2)  ILLEGAL BUILDINGS. All buildings erected, repaired or altered in violation of the provisions of this Code relating to materials and manner of construction of buildings and structures within the City. 
(3)  UNAUTHORIZED TRAFFIC SIGNS. All unauthorized signs, signals, markings or devices placed or maintained upon or in view of any public highway or railway crossing which purport to be or may be mistaken as an official traffic control device, railroad sign or signal or which, because of its color, location, brilliance or manner of operation, interferes with the effectiveness of any device, sign or signal. 
(4)  OBSTRUCTION OF INTERSECTIONS. All trees, hedges, billboards or other obstructions, which prevent persons driving vehicles on public streets, alleys or highways from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching in intersection or pedestrian crosswalk and which obstruct the clear vision triangle. 
(5)  TREE LIMBS. All limbs of trees which project over and less than 14 feet above any public sidewalk or less than 20 feet above a street or other public place. 
(6)  DANGEROUS TREES. All trees which are a menace to public safety or are the cause of substantial annoyance to the general public and which may be diseased, dead, dying, cracked or at risk of falling and endanger the life, health, safety or welfare of the public or its property. 
(7)  FIREWORKS. All use or display of fireworks, except as provided by the laws of the State and this Code. 
(8)  DILAPIDATED BUILDINGS. All buildings or structures so old, dilapidated or out of repair as to be dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human use. 
(9)  WIRES OVER STREETS. All wires over streets, alleys or public grounds which are strung less than 15 feet above the surface thereof. 
(10)  NOISY ANIMALS OR FOWL. The keeping or harboring of any animal or fowl which, by frequent or habitual howling, yelping, barking, crowing or making of other noises, shall greatly annoy or disturb a neighborhood or any considerable number of persons within the City. 
(11)  OBSTRUCTIONS OF STREETS, EXCAVATIONS. All obstructions of streets, alleys, sidewalks or crosswalks and all excavations in or under the same, except as permitted by this Code, or which, although made in accordance with this Code, are kept or maintained for an unreasonable or illegal length of time after the purpose thereof has been accomplished, or do not conform to the permit. 
(12)  UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLY. Any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public street, alley or sidewalk or of a public street, alley or sidewalk which causes large crowds to gather, obstructing traffic and free use of the streets or sidewalks. 
(13)  SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL. All ice not removed from public sidewalks or sprinkled with a material which reduces the risk to pedestrians of slipping and falling and all snow not removed from public sidewalks within 24 hours after it has ceased to fall thereon. (See also sec. 8.09(1).) 
(14)  REFRIGERATORS. All abandoned refrigerators or iceboxes from which the doors and other covers have not been removed or which are not equipped with a device for opening from the inside. 
(15)  FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS VIOLATIONS. Repeated or continuous violations of this Code or the laws of the State relating to the storage of flammable liquids. 
10.06, 10.07 - RESERVED . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #02-15(2015)) 
10.08 - ABATEMENT OF PUBLIC NUISANCES . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #02-15(2015)) 
(1)  ENFORCEMENT (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #04-16(2016)). The Chief of Police, the Chief of the Fire Department, Director of Community and Economic Development or designee, Code Compliance Officer, Building Inspector, Director of Public Works, Street Superintendent and City Forester shall enforce those provisions of this chapter that come within the jurisdiction of their respective offices, and they shall make periodic inspections and inspections upon complaint to insure that such provisions are not violated. No action shall be taken under this section to abate a public nuisance unless the officer shall have inspected or cause to be inspected the premises where the nuisance is alleged to exist and has satisfied himself/herself that a nuisance does, in fact, exist. 
(2)  SUMMARY ABATEMENT. If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance exists within the City and that there is great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the Mayor may direct the proper officer to cause the same to be abated and charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance, as the case may be. 
(3)  ABATEMENT AFTER NOTICE. If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance exists on private premises, but that the nature of such nuisance is not such as to threaten great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, he/she shall serve notice on the person causing or maintaining the nuisance to remove the same within 10 days. If such nuisance is not removed within said 10 days, the property officer shall cause the nuisance to be removed, as provided in sub. (2). 
(4)  OTHER METHODS NOT EXCLUDED. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the abatement of public nuisances by the City or its officials in accordance with the laws of the State. 
(5)  COURT ORDER. Except when necessary under sub. (2), no officer hereunder shall use force to obtain access to private property to abate a public nuisance, but shall request permission to enter upon private property if such premises are occupied, and, if such permission is denied, shall apply to any court having jurisdiction for an order assisting the abatement of the public nuisance. 
10.09 - COST OF ABATEMENT . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #02-15(2015)) 
In addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection, contrivance, creation, continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the City shall be collected as a debt from the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance, and, if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner, such cost shall be assessed against the real estate as a special charge. 
10.10 - TREES, SHRUBS AND OTHER VEGETATION . (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #02-15(2015)) 
(1)  INTENT. It is the intent of this section to exercise jurisdiction in regard to promote, maintain and improve the urban forest by addressing planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and other vegetation growing in public places in the City. The ordinance provides full power and authority over all public trees, plants and shrubs and to trees plants and shrubs located on private property that constitute a public nuisance, hazard or threat and provide for their abatement. 
(2)  DEFINITIONS. In this section, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the following words and terms shall have the meaning given herein: 
(a)  City Forester. The Director of Public Works (or designee) is the designated City official assigned to carry out the enforcement of this section. The Director (or designee) shall be considered the City Forester for purposes of this section and any other section of this Code relating to trees, shrubs, and other vegetation. 
(b)  Clear Vision Triangle. The triangle generated for a point starting at the street corner (right-of-way) of a private corner lot running 10 feet down each private property line to a point. 
(c)  Public Area. That part of every street, highway, roadway or alley between the private lot line and the curb or pavement and any other land owned or controlled by the City. 
(d)  Public Nuisance. Any tree, shrub or other vegetation within the city which is specifically designated a public nuisance in this section or part of which is on public or private property which, by reason of its condition, interferes with the use of any public place; is detrimental to the construction of public improvements; or endangers the life, health, safety or welfare of the public or its property. 
(e)  Street Tree. Any tree located in a terrace. 
(f)  Terrace. The part of every street between the private lot line and the curb or pavement line. 
(3)  CITY FORESTER, POWERS AND DUTIES. It shall be the duty of the City Forester, under the supervision of the City Council, to enforce the provisions of this section. The powers and duties of the City Forester are as follows: 
(a)  The City Forester shall have the jurisdiction, authority, control and supervision over all trees, shrubs and other vegetation growing in public areas to include, but not be limited to, planting, removal, maintenance and protection to insure safety or preserve the aesthetics of public sites. 
(b)  The City Forester shall have the authority to grant approvals under the provisions of this section and rules and work standards adopted hereunder. He/she shall supervise all work done under any approval issued under the provisions of this section and may void any approval if the provisions of this section are not complied with. 
(c)  The City Forester shall have the authority to cause a public nuisance to be abated in accordance with the provisions of this section. Upon identifying that a tree/bush/shrub on public property is a public nuisance and must be removed, the city shall notify adjacent property owners prior to tree removal. 
The City Forester may inspect any trees, shrubs, vines, plants, logs or branches existing or growing upon any private or public property within the City. The City Forester may conduct surveys to determine if any destructive or communicable disease or other pest exists which may be detrimental to or endanger the good health of trees or other plant life in the City. 
(d)  The City Forester shall perform such other duties as are provided by the laws, rules and regulations of the State, particularly §27.09, Wis. Stats. 
(4)  TREE PLANTING REQUIREMENTS. 
(a)  Approval Required. No person shall plant any tree or shrub or other vegetation in a public area without the approval of the City Forester. 
(b)  Master Street Tree List. The City Council shall approve a master street tree list consisting of those trees approved for planting in and on City streets along with a determination of site factors to be considered in selecting trees and placement of such trees for planting on a particular street. 
(c)  Improper Planting a Public Nuisance. Any tree planted in violation of this section shall be deemed a public nuisance. 
(5)  TREE MAINTENANCE. 
(a)  No person shall remove, maintain or protect any public tree or shrub or cause such work to be done without obtaining approval from the City Forester. No approval is required to cultivate, water or fertilize any public tree or shrub or take the necessary action to guard the public safety or clear the public way in the event of a storm, accident or other emergency. 
(b)  Any person desiring to remove, maintain or protect any public tree or shrub shall apply, in writing, to the City Forester for approval to do such work. The application shall specify the location and description of the proposed work. If the City Forester determines that the proposed work is necessary and in compliance with the purposes of this section, he/she shall approve the work. 
(c)  Whenever a public utility or its contractors or any contractor for the City must perform work on or about any public tree or shrub necessitating the alteration above or below ground, trimming, or removal of such tree or shrub, approval from the City Forester is required, as provided above. Any person performing work on a tree in a public place, by permit, contract or otherwise, shall assume full responsibility for damage to property and to any person and shall save the City harmless from any liability therefore. 
(d)  All trees and shrubs located upon any public way or upon any private premises adjacent to the public way shall be kept trimmed by the property owner so that the lowest projecting branches provide a clearance height of not less than 20 feet above the public street and not less than 14 feet above the public sidewalk. The City Forester may waive the provisions of this section for newly planted or naturally low-profile trees if he/she determines that such trees do not interfere with public travel, obstruct the light of any street light, obstruct the view of any traffic sign or signal or endanger public safety. 
(6)  PROTECTION OF TREES. Except as approved by the City Forester, it shall be a violation of this section to perform or cause to be performed the following acts in any public place within the City: 
(a)  To attach any sign, poster, handbill, electrical installation wire or other devise or material to, around or through a tree. 
(b)  To permit or cause fire to burn where it may kill or injure any tree. 
(c)  To allow any toxic chemical, smoke, oil, gas or other substance that may kill or damage any tree to come in contact with its leaves or roots. 
(d)  To use tree spurs or climbers when working on healthy trees. 
(e)  To remove any guard, stake, pole or other device intended for the protection or stabilization of a public tree, or close or obstruct any open space around the base of a public tree designed to permit access to air, water and fertilizer. 
(f)  To erect, alter, repair, raze or move any building, structure or other large object without placing suitable guards around public trees which may be injured by such operations. Tree crowns and trunks shall not suffer any branch or bark loss. Roots shall be protected from compaction, storage of materials, and severing within a circle around the tree with the tree trunk as the focal point. The radius of the Tree Protection Zone (TPZ) shall be determined by the tree diameter listed in the following table: 
Tree Diameter 4.5 feet above ground Radius of TPZ (tree trunk in center) 0-4 in. 2 feet 4.1-9 in. 5 feet 9.1-14 in. 10 feet 14.1-19 in. 12 feet 19.1 in. or more 15 feet  
Roots located within the determined circle shall be protected by such practices as temporary bridges for vehicles or auguring for utility installation. Any factors that would cause any deviations from the above tale shall be noted on the permit issued for such work and require notification of the City Forester. 
It shall be the responsibility of the owner thereof to repair or replace any tree injured or killed by such operations. If it is found that the moving of any tree is necessary to allow for such operations, the cost of the moving shall be borne by the owner of the project. 
(g)  To excavate any ditch, tunnel, hole or trench, or to place any drive within the radius of 5 feet from any tree in a public area except by approval from the City Forester or when an emergency situation exists. The City Forester may require the posting of an adequate surety bond or other sufficient security by any person proposing to make any such excavation to cover the cost of replacement of any tree destroyed as the direct result of the excavation as reasonably determined by the Forester. 
(h)  To damage, injure, remove or appropriate for one's own personal or private use any tree or shrub procured in whole or in part with public funds or planted or growing in a public area. 
(i)  To prune Oak trees on public or private property from April 1 to October 1, except by approval from the City Forester. If wounding of Oak trees occurs during this time under any circumstances, a nontoxic tree wound dressing may be applied. 
(j)  Violations. Any person found to disturb the root zone, prune, remove or cause the removal or death of any public tree, shrub or other plant as well as any other violation of Chapter 10 without approval of the City Forester shall be subject to a forfeiture as identified in sec. 25.04. 
(k)  Emergencies. The Mayor, with City Council approval in the case of emergencies such as windstorms, ice storms or other disasters may waive the requirements of this ordinance so that they in no way shall hinder private or public work to restore order in the City. 
(7)  PLANTING OF OTHER VEGETATION REQUIREMENTS. 
(a)  Approval required. No person shall plant any other vegetation, except for grass for lawns, in a public area without the approval of the City Forester. 
(b)  Any and all vegetation planted in public areas shall not exceed a height of 24 inches excluding street trees. 
(8)  OBSTRUCTION OF VIEW AT INTERSECTIONS. No person shall plant, grow or maintain any tree, shrub or other vegetation on any City street corner lot within the private property clear vision triangle which may obstruct the vision of the operator of any motor vehicle or pedestrian approaching such intersection. Any tree, shrub or other vegetation obstructing such view between the heights of 21/2 feet and 14 feet above street grade shall be deemed a public nuisance. 
(9)  PUBLIC NUISANCES. No person shall permit any public nuisance enumerated in this section to remain on any property owned or controlled by him/her, including public areas. 
(a)  Notice of Public Nuisance. The City Forester or designee shall have the authority to inspect or cause to be inspected all premises and places to determine whether any public nuisance as defined in this article exists, and shall also inspect or cause to be inspected any vegetation reported or suspected to be infected with disease or insects. 
The City Forester may enter upon private premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of carrying out any of the provisions of this article. Whenever the City Forester shall find and declare any tree or part thereof, shrub or other vegetation that constitutes a hazard to life or property in the public right-of-way or on public property or public nuisance, he/she shall notify the property owner or his or her agent in writing that the nuisance must be abated and the procedure required for the abatement. If the owner of the property fails or refuses to take remedial action, the City or the agent of, shall have the authority to enter the property and perform the remedial action without compensation to such owner, as well as submit an invoice for payment to be reimbursed by the private property owner to the City for all City incurred expenses. 
If the City Forester ascertains that any tree or part thereof or shrub growing on private property is dead, declining, infected with communicable disease or insect infestation which threatens the health of the urban forest or endangers public or private property, the City Forester may notify the owner of the property that the tree or shrub must be treated or removed within 30 days of the notification, unless it is determined to be an immediate danger to health and safety The following conditions are exemplary, but not an inclusive list of matters declared to be public nuisances; 
1.  Any dead, dangerous or diseased tree 
2.  Any Elm tree infected with Dutch Elm Disease fungus or which harbors any carrier of the same 
3.  Any oak tree infected with Oak Wilt 
4.  Any ash tree infested with Emerald Ash Borer 
5.  Any tree, bush, shrub or other plant which is infested with and insect or disease capable of infesting other plants 
(b)  Abatement Procedure and Cost. See secs. 10.08 and 10.09. 
(10)  NOXIOUS WEEDS AND MAINTENANCE OF VEGETATION. (Rep. & Recr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this Section to prohibit the uncontrolled growth of vegetation and to control noxious weeds and invasive species, while permitting the planting and maintenance of planned natural landscaping that add diversity and richness to the quality of life. There are reasonable expectations regarding the proper maintenance of vegetation on any lot or parcel of land. It is in the public's interests to provide standards regarding the maintenance of vegetation because vegetation which is not managed can decrease the value of nearby properties and threaten the public health and safety. It is also in the public's interests to encourage diverse landscaping treatments, particularly those that encourage the preservation, restoration, and management of native plant communities which can be economical, low-maintenance and effective in soil and water conservation. The City enacts this Section to balance these competing interests. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(b)  Definitions. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Destroy means the complete killing of weeds or the killing of weed plants above the surface of the ground by the use of chemicals, cutting, tillage, cropping system, or any or all of these in effective combination, at a time and in a manner as will effectively prevent the weed plants from maturing to bloom or flower stage. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Garden means a cultivated area dedicated to growing vegetables and fruits in a well-defined location. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Native Plants means those grasses (including prairie grasses), sedges (solid, triangular-stemmed plants resembling grasses), forbs (flowering broadleaf plants) that are native to or naturalized to the State of Wisconsin. Native plants do not include weeds. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Noxious Weeds means any plant listed under Wisconsin Invasive Species Rule (Ch. NR 40, Wis. Admin. Code) and shall also include but not be limited to the following: (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(1)  Canada Thistle or other thistles. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(2)  English Carloc or Wild Mustard. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(3)  Field Bindweed, commonly known as Creeping Jenny. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(4)  Burdock. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(5)  Ragweed. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(6)  Poison Ivy. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(7)  Leafy Spurge. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(8)  Purple Loosestrife. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(9)  Stinging/Burning Nettle. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(10)  Multiflora Rose. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(11)  Buckthorn. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(12)  Wild Parsnip. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(13)  Cocklebur. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(14)  Pigweed. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(15)  Smartweed. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(16)  Garlic Mustard. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Ornamental Grasses and Groundcovers means grasses and groundcovers not indigenous to Wisconsin. Ornamental grasses do not include turf grasses and weeds. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Planned Natural Landscaping means a planned, intentional and maintained planting of native plants, ornamental grasses and groundcovers, rain gardens, shrubs and trees. Planned natural landscaping does not include any species of turf grasses and is not intended to allow a property owner to ignore lawn care duties. Planned natural landscaping does not include gardens. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Rain Garden means a native plant garden that is designed not only to aesthetically improve properties, but also to reduce the amount of storm water and accompanying pollutants from entering streams, rivers and lakes. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
Turf Grasses means grasses commonly used in regularly cut lawns or play areas including bluegrass, fescue or rye grass blends or any other similar grasses. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(c)  Control of Noxious Weeds. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(1)  As provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.0407, the City shall require that all noxious weeds shall be destroyed prior to the time in which such plants would mature to the bloom or flower state. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(2)  Any undeveloped parcel larger than one acre in size shall destroy noxious weeds and cut long grass and vegetation to 12 inches in height within the right of way and within 20 feet of any abutting developed property. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(3)  Any parcel with improvement upon it or a parcel less than one acre in size shall destroy noxious weeds and cut and maintain long grass and vegetation to a height of 12 inches or less. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(4)  This section shall not apply to: (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(a)  Gardens, (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(b)  Plants located on shoreland within 35 feet of the ordinary high-water mark, (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(c)  Plants located within environmentally sensitive areas such as steep slopes, drainage ways, wetlands, and protective buffer areas, or (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(d)  Planned natural landscaping that is wholly contained within the parcel on which it is planted and maintained. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
The cost of destroying the weeds shall be charged and assessed in the manner provided by Section 10.09 of this code. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(d)  Requirement of Planned Natural Landscaping. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(1)  Turf grass is to be eliminated and the native plants, trees and shrubs are to be planted through transplanting or seed by humans or mechanical means. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(2)  Setbacks. The setback area shall be regularly cut turf grass, trees, shrubs, mulch, wood chips, or landscape stone. Setbacks are distances are defined as: (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(a)  Five feet from front lot line when adjacent to a public sidewalk and 0 feet from front lot line if there is no public sidewalk. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(b)  Five feet from rear and side lot lines. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(c)  No setback is required on side and rear lot lines if any of the following conditions exist: (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
i.  There is a sight-tight fence along the lot lines. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
ii.  The native landscaping abuts a neighboring planned natural landscaping area. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
iii.  The native landscaping abuts a public park/ open space. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
iv.  The native landscaping abuts a natural area. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(3)  Application. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(a)  Any owner of land in the City of Waupaca may apply for approval of a planned natural landscaping, where the grasses exceed 12 inches in height and consist of non-invasive native Wisconsin vegetation, with the Community and Economic Development Department. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(b)  A planned natural landscaping means site and written plans relating to management of the lawn which contains setback distances of the lawn upon which the plantings will exceed 12 inches of height, a statement of intent and purpose for the lawn, a description of the vegetation types, plants and plant succession involved and the specific management and maintenance techniques to be employed. The management plan must include provisions for cutting at a length not greater than 12 inches in the setback area. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(c)  When, in the opinion of the Fire Chief, the presence of a planned natural landscaping may constitute a fire or safety hazard due to weather and/ or other conditions, the Fire Chief may order the cutting of the planned natural landscaping to safe conditions. As a condition of receiving approval of the planned natural landscaping permit, the property owner shall be required to cut the planned natural landscaping within the 3 days upon receiving written direction from the Fire Chief. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(e)  Enforcement and Penalties. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(1)  Upon receipt of a complaint of unmanaged plant growth and/or noxious weeds, the Code Compliance Officer or designee will inspect any lot or property adjacent to or adjoining a lot to review compliance with provisions of this ordinance. If violations are noted, the Code Compliance Officer or designee shall on the first violation of the season notify the party responsible for the property that shall request compliance within 7 days from the date of the notice. Said notice shall inform the owner that subsequent violations during the current season shall be corrected by the City without further notice. If such violation is not corrected within 7 days, the City will authorize and conduct action to bring the property into compliance and bill the property owner for such efforts under section 10.09 and 25.04. The City shall bring the property into compliance and bill the property for each violation thereafter. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(2)  Code Compliance Officer or designee shall have the authority to revoke an approved planned natural landscaping permit if the owner fails to maintain the planned natural landscaping or comply with the provisions set forth in this section. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017)) 
(11)  APPEALS. Any person aggrieved by any order or action of the City Forester may file a written complaint with the City Council. The City Council shall act upon that complaint at a future regularly scheduled meeting upon providing reasonable notice of the meeting to the aggrieved party. (Cr. Ord. #03-17(2017))

10.15 - PENALTY . 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or permit or cause a public nuisance shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec. 25.04 of this Code.

11.01 - RESERVED . (Rep. Ord. #17-96) 
11.02 - RULES AND REGULATIONS . 
The Finance Committee may make reasonable and general rules for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and for the prevention of the creation of health nuisances and the protection of the public health and welfare and may, where appropriate, require the issuance of licenses and permits. All such regulations, when approved by the Council, shall have the same effect as ordinances and any person violating any of such regulations and any lawful order of the Committee shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec. 25.04 of this Code. 
11.03 - HEALTH NUISANCES, ABATEMENT OF . (Am. Ord. #17-95) 
The Building Inspector, together with the Finance Committee, may abate health nuisances in accordance with §145.14, Wis. Stats., which is adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein. 
11.04 - COMMUNICABLE DISEASES . (Am. Ord. #17-95) 
Chapter 143, Wis. Stats., and Wis. Adm. Code H 45 are adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter and the Building Inspector and the Finance Committee shall enforce the provisions thereof. 
11.05 - REGULATION OF NUISANCE-TYPE BUSINESSES . 
(1)  PERMIT REQUIRED. No person shall conduct within the City any business which has a tendency to create a public nuisance, except upon permit issued by the Finance Committee and subject to such conditions as the Committee may impose. 
(2)  DEFINITION. A business which has a tendency to create a public nuisance, as defined in sec. 10.02 of this Code, unless properly regulated. 
(3)  AUTHORITY. This section is enacted pursuant to §66.0415, Wis. Stats. 
11.06 - COMPULSORY CONNECTION TO SEWER AND WATER . (Am. Ord. #25-04; Rep. & Recr. Ord. #04-10) 
(1)  All buildings used for human habitation shall be connected with the City sewer and water system, if available, within 90 days after notice from the Building Inspector. 
(2)  If any property owner fails to comply within 90 days of receiving notice, the City may cause such connection to be made and the expense thereof shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property to be paid in full at the time of assessment. If the amount of the assessment is over the amount of $100, the property owner, within 30 days after the completion of work, may file a written request with the City Clerk asking that the assessment be levied as follows: an amount from $100 to $500 to be paid in 5 equal annual installments; over $500 to be paid in 8 equal annual installments. The amount so assessed shall accrue interest from the date of completion of the work until paid, at a rate of 2% per annum over the prime rate, which accrued interest shall be collected at the time of payment of each installment. 
(3)  In lieu of the above, the City, at its option, may impose a penalty for the period that the violation continues after 10 days written notice to any owner failing to make a connection to the sewer or water system of an amount equal to 150% of the minimum monthly charge for sewer and water service payable monthly for the period in which the failure to connect continues and, upon failure to make such payment, said charge shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property, all pursuant to §144.06, Wis. Stats. 
(4)  [Availability; Exemption.] 
(a)  Sewer and water shall be deemed available if the building used for human sanitation is located on property that is adjacent to a water or sewer main, or in a block through which sewer and water mains extend. 
(b)  In any case that sewer and water is deemed available as provided under para. (a), the property owner may apply to the Board of Public Works for an exemption if the owner believes it to be a hardship to connect to the system. 
(c)  In determining hardship, the Board of Public Works shall consider the cost to the property owner to connect or to hookup to the City sewer or water system, any adverse effects there may be on the environment caused by the noncompliance with this ordinance and any other condition that may exist at the time the application is made for exemption. 
(5)  Properties that are serviced by a private sewage system or a private well at the time that this ordinance shall come in force, shall not be required to hookup to the sewer system or water system until such sewer system or water system shall fail. 
(a)  A failed private sewage system shall be defined as provided in §145.245(4), Wis. Stats. 
(b)  A failed private water system shall be defined as a system that is not in compliance with the Department of Natural Resources standard as provided under Wisconsin Administrative Code NR Chapter 809 and Chapter 812. 
11.07 - MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS . 
(1)  No person shall sell or distribute milk or any milk product, as hereinafter defined, for direct human consumption or to any hotel, restaurant, store, vendor or other retailer for resale for human consumption unless such person possesses a valid license therefor granted under sec. 12.18 of this Code. No license shall be required for hotels, restaurants, stores, vendors and other retailers who sell the milk and milk products furnished by licensees in compliance with this section. 
(2)  For the purpose of this section, the term "milk product" shall mean and include cream, homogenized milk, buttermilk, skim milk, milk beverages, skim milk beverages, milk or skim milk which have been fortified by the addition of vitamins or minerals. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to sell, offer or expose for sale any milk or milk product which is adulterated or misbranded as those terms are defined in the Wisconsins statutes. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful to sell, offer or expose for sale any milk or milk product other than Grade A pasteurized milk and milk products as those terms are defined in General Order No. AG80. 
(5)  The Building Inspector or other person designated by him/her shall enforce this section. (Am. Ord. #17-96) 
11.08 - GARBAGE AND REFUSE . 
(1)  DEFINITIONS. (Am. Ord. #5-90) In this section, unless the context requires otherwise, the definitions contained in Ch. 144, Wis. Stats., are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this section as if fully set forth herein. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated herein are intended to be made part of this section. 
(a)  Garbage. Includes all kinds of organic kitchen waste resulting from the preparation of food and all decayed foods and food products from any source whatsoever. 
(b)  Refuse. Includes all waste matter such as ashes, tin cans, glass, rags, garden refuse and other items of a similar nature, but shall not include leaves, trees, tree limbs, earth, stone or manure. 
(c)  Commercial Waste. Any refuse that accumulates in or upon property used for wholesale or retail commercial purposes. 
(d)  Industrial Waste. Any refuse that accumulates in or upon property used for manufacturing or industrial purposes. 
(e)  Hazardous Waste. Any solid waste identified by the State Department of Natural Resources as hazardous under §144.62(2)(a), Wis. Stats. 
(f)  Owner. Includes a person in lawful possession and control of the property or the refuse container. 
(2)  KEEPING OF REGULATED. 
(a)  No person shall deposit, throw or place any garbage or refuse on or within any public street, alley, park, sidewalk or other public place, or within or upon any private property or premises, whether owned, kept or controlled by such person or not in the City, unless the same shall be placed in containers as hereinafter provided, or disposed of through a mechanical unit connected to a sanitary sewer or interior residential garbage burner. 
(b)  No person shall deposit, throw or place leaves, trees, tree limbs, earth, stone or manure on or within any public street, alley, park, sidewalk or other public place. 
(c)  No person shall burn or bury any garbage on private or public property in the City, but shall cause the same to be collected or disposed of in the manner herein provided. No person shall burn any refuse or other material unless same is done in an approved refuse burner or fireplace. 
(d)  All garbage shall be well drained and wrapped securely in newspapers and deposited in containers that shall be kept closed with a tight fitting cover, except when being filled or emptied, shall be vermin and flyproof and kept in a sanitary condition. 
(e)  All refuse, including commercial and industrial waste, shall be placed in cans, baskets or other suitable containers until disposed of in the manner hereinafter provided, and all boxes not used as refuse containers must be broken down flat. 
(3)  COLLECTION. 
(a)  Garbage and refuse collection services shall be maintained upon a voluntary basis with each resident or firm desirous of such services contracting for them as was customary prior to the passage of this section. 
(b)  (Rep. Ord. #5-90) 
(4)  DISPOSAL. 
(a)  Disposal of Solid Waste; Consent of Owner Required . (Rep. and Recr. Ord. #5-90) No person shall dump or place any solid waste, garbage, refuse or ashes on any property in the City without the consent of the owner of such property. 
(b)  Unauthorized Use of Receptacle; General . (Rep. and Recr. Ord. #5-90) No person shall place, or permit another to place, any solid waste, garbage, refuse or ashes in any refuse container in the City without the consent of the owner of the refuse container. 
(c)  Unauthorized Use of Receptacles; City-Owned Receptacles . (Rep. and Recr. Ord. #5-90) No person shall place, or permit another to place, any solid waste, garbage, refuse or ashes in any refuse container in a City park if such waste is not generated as a result of the use of the park. No person shall place, or permit another to place, any solid waste, garbage, refuse or ashes in any City-owned refuse containers, located on public streets, unless such waste is generated incidental to the use of public sidewalks or streets. No person shall place, or permit another to place, any solid waste, garbage, refuse or ashes in any City-owned refuse containers if such waste is generated from household, commercial or industrial sources. 
(d)  No person shall disturb, remove or carry away any rubbish, refuse or any matter or thing that has been dumped, placed or deposited at the sanitary landfill unless approved in writing by the Director of Public Works. 
(e)  The collection and disposal of garbage and refuse, as described herein, shall be conducted under the supervision, direction and control of the Director of Public Works in strict conformity with the provisions of this section and with such additional rules and regulations as may be made, from time to time, by the Finance Committee. 
(f)  Reserved. (Rep. Ord. #5-90) 
(5)  DISPOSAL OF HAZARDOUS WASTE AND OIL PROHIBITED. (Am. Ord. # 01-04) No person shall deposit hazardous waste or any oil product in the City sanitary landfill site, nor set out such hazardous waste or oil product for collection by a licensed garbage collector. No garbage collector licensed under sec. 12.14 of this Code shall knowingly deposit any hazardous waste or oil product in the City sanitary landfill site. Any person desiring to dispose of hazardous waste or oil may contact the City Clerk regarding such disposal. 
(6)  RESERVED. (Rep. Ord. #29-89, Eff. 4-1-90; Rerep. Ord. #5-90) 
(7)  RESERVED. (Rep. Ord. #5-90) 
(8)  RESERVED. (Rep. Ord. #5-90) 
11.09 - LITTERING WATER WITHIN CITY PROHIBITED . 
No person shall deposit, place or throw into any waters within the City or leave upon the ice thereof cans, bottles, debris, refuse or other solid waste material. 
11.15 - PENALTY . 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or any order, rule or regulation made hereunder shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec. 25.04 of this Code.
